PLEASE NOTE: Because of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!
results.how_to_find_us: We're meeting on the second floor in the Kuumba Library.  Enter the main entrance on Clarendon Street, take the spiral staircase to the right, and we're in the room to the right.  See you there!
results.name: Study 2 Corinthians

results.description:
http://chimamanda.com/books/americanah/

Ifemelu and Obinze are young and in love when they depart military-ruled Nigeria for the West. Beautiful, self-assured Ifemelu heads for America, where despite her academic success, she is forced to grapple with what it means to be black for the first time. Quiet, thoughtful Obinze had hoped to join her, but with post-9/11 America closed to him, he instead plunges into a dangerous, undocumented life in London. Fifteen years later, they reunite in a newly democratic Nigeria, and reignite their passion—for each other and for their homeland.

results.description:
There was a lot of draw last week, and a number of people (myself included weren't able to make it, so we're offering a round 2/ open to anyone who's interested).  Hope you can make it!

How valuable is friendship to modern adult life? What are the advantages and challenges that are unique to our culture? 

Julie Beck, in the Atlantic article below, begins with the statement that, "In the hierarchy of relationships, friendships are at the bottom." Yet, she argues, that they are essential for our well-being. 

How important is it to cultivate past friendships? How important is it to develop new friendships?

If you get a chance, here's the article: http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/10/how-friendships-change-over-time-in-adulthood/411466/

results.description:
The Boston Austrian Economics Group will discuss the revolutionaries of the Marginal Revolution, including Austrian School founder Carl Menger, as well as its counter-revolutionaries.

READING

"The Retarded Acceptance of Marginal Utility Theory" by Emil Kauder

Study Questions

1. Did the British classical economists help or hamper the development of marginal utility theory?

2. Who is the earliest writer to touch on marginal utility theory? What other schools of economics had an early version of marginal utility theory?

3. Who was the first person to mathematize marginal utility theory?

4. Who was the first person to put the final piece in the puzzle that is marginal utility theory? What was this piece?

5. Was Turgot’s theory of marginal utility substantially different from Wicksell’s? Did Adam Smith have any excuse for not knowing Turgot’s theory? Did Smith have an excuse for not knowing Aristotle’s?

6. Why does Kauder think that the protestant economists were so slow to accept marginal utility theory?

7. If the problem with Calvinism is the glorification of labor, what is the problem with Aristotilian-Scholastic theory?

8. Why is Adam Smith’s theory necessary to Calvinist theology? How does Aristotle see work and pleasure, and why did Aristotle’s ideas see more prominence in the Catholic countries?

9. What did Marshall get wrong in his theory of marginal utility?

10. What was the historical school’s role in the development of marginal utility?
results.how_to_find_us: Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.
results.name: The Marginal Revolution

The Boston Dyke March is an amazing alt-Pride event that gives space and voice to those often overshadowed both in society and in the queer community. We are intersectional and inclusive -the Dyke March is for EVERYONE, regardless of gender identity, orientation, age, religion, race, background, or ability. Want be part of something big in your community while meeting new people and having fun? We'd love to have you!

In addition to the March itself in June, we plan events and activities throughout the year, have fun Committee social outings, advocate for social change, and generally be awesome. We're looking to shake things up and grow, and we want you to be part of that. We are a consensus based, grassroots, totally volunteer-run group, so every voice matters. We hope to see you there!

(Meeting is taking place in the Mass NOW and NARAL Pro Choice MA conference room in Suite 900. Office is near State, Park, and Downtown Crossing T stations.)

results.description:
The epic story of the rise and fall of the empire of cotton, its centrality to the world economy, and its making and remaking of global capitalism.<a href="http://www.royallhouse.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/EmpireOfCotton_bookcover.jpg"></a> Cotton is so ubiquitous as to be almost invisible, yet understanding its history is key to understanding the origins of modern capitalism. Sven Beckert’s rich, fascinating book tells the story of how, in a remarkably brief period, European entrepreneurs and powerful statesmen recast the world’s most significant manufacturing industry, combining imperial expansion and slave labor with new machines and wage workers to change the world. Here is the story of how, beginning well before the advent of machine production in the 1780s, these men captured ancient trades and skills in Asia, and combined them with the expropriation of lands in the Americas and the enslavement of African workers to crucially reshape the disparate realms of cotton that had existed for millennia, and how industrial capitalism gave birth to an empire, and how this force transformed the world.

$5.00
results.name: Empire of Cotton: A Global History, an Illustrated book talk

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Come join us for our first Node.JS Boston meetup of 2016!  As usual, amazing speakers and free food and booze. Hope to see many of you there!

- Brian

------------------------------

Gleb Bahmutov, Kensho

‘NodeJS Security’

A simple technique to disable the script injection attacks on your web pages is to disable the inline JavaScript. This means that most popular ways to inject variables and code fragments into your pages will have to change. I will show the JavaScript to JavaScript rendering engine for Express that allows you to set very strict and safe Content-Security-Policy on your website. Not only my approach is much safer, but it will be very testable as well.

In the second part of the presentation I will show my current work on preventing sensitive information leaking accidentally to the public GitHub repo or being published to the NPM registry. This is extremely common, and most popular NPM packages had private information leaked at some point (See "Do not underestimate credentials leaks" at https://github.com/ChALkeR/notes/blob/master/Do-not-underestimate-credentials-leaks.md)

Gleb Bahmutov is JavaScript ninja, image processing expert and software quality fanatic. After receiving a PhD in computer science from Purdue University, Gleb worked on laser scanners, 3D reconstruction, and panorama-based virtual tours at EveryScape. Later Gleb switched to writing browser data visualization software at MathWorks. After a year, Gleb went back to the startup environment and developed software quality analysis tools at uTest (now Applause). 

Today Gleb is developing real-time financial analysis tools at Kensho. He blogs about software development topics at http://glebbahmutov.com/blog/ and links his projects at http://glebbahmutov.com/. You can follow him and his work @bahmutov


Daniel Khan

'NodeJS Performance'

If there is bad press about our favorite server side platform it is because of performance issues and how hard it is to track them down. Usually these problems are hiding during development but start to kick in under high load. Not good.

In my talk we will go through the “hall of fame" of Node.js performance problems and the error patterns behind them.Then we will take a pleasant walk to “Mount Doom" … this means we will learn how to create and decipher flame charts to hunt and understand memory leaks. 

By doing so, we will even look at some C++ code and get some insights on how Node.js is working internally.After taking the hard road we will explore tools and techniques that help us to tackle performance issues more easily – even during development.

Daniel has over 15 years experience as full stack developer, architect and technical lead in the field of web engineering proving his strong problem solving skills in hundreds of projects. 

He is passionate about constant learning, using new technologies and sharing his findings with others. 

As Technologie Lead, Daniel focuses on driving support for emerging technologies like Node.js and MongoDB at Dynatrace.

Jeff Whelpley, Chief Architect at GetHuman

`Full-stack 'ES6'`

There is a huge wave of innovation in the JavaScript community that is just starting to hit with the arrival of ES6 and all of the tooling being built around it. In this talk, Jeff Whelpley will demonstrate how you can most effectively leverage all of this to build ultra-fast, powerful full-stack JavaScript applications.

results.description:
Boston Herald
A heroic action-thriller, “The Finest Hours” is the remarkable true story of the greatest small boat rescue in Coast Guard history. Presented in Digital 3D™ and IMAX® 3D, the film will transport audiences to the heart of the action, creating a fully-immersive cinematic experience on an epic scale. On February 18, 1952, a massive nor’easter struck New England, pummeling towns along the Eastern seaboard and wreaking havoc on the ships caught in its deadly path, including the SS Pendleton, a T-2 oil tanker bound for Boston, which was literally ripped in half, trapping more than 30 sailors inside its rapidly-sinking stern. As the senior officer on board, first assistant engineer Ray Sybert (Casey Affleck) soon realizes it is up to him to take charge of the frightened crew and inspire the men to set aside their differences and work together to ride out one of the worst storms to ever hit the East Coast. Meanwhile, as word of the disaster reaches the U.S. Coast Guard station in Chatham, Massachusetts, Warrant Officer Daniel Cluff (Eric Bana) orders a daring operation to rescue the stranded men. Despite overwhelming odds, four men, led by Coast Guard Captain Bernie Webber (Chris Pine), set out in a wooden lifeboat with an ill-equipped engine and little, if any, means of navigation, facing frigid temperatures, 60-foot high waves and hurricane-force winds.

Disney’s “The Finest Hours” is the unforgettable story of the Coast Guard’s courageous mission, which is directed by Craig Gillespie and stars: Chris Pine; Academy Award® and Golden Globe® nominee Casey Affleck; Ben Foster; Holliday Grainger; John Ortiz; and Eric Bana. Produced by Jim Whitaker and Dorothy Aufiero, the screenplay is by Oscar® nominee Scott Silver and Oscar nominees Paul Tamasy & Eric Johnson based on the acclaimed non-fiction book of the same name by Michael J. Tougias and Casey Sherman. Doug Merrifield serves as executive producer. “The Finest Hours” storms into U.S. theaters on January 29, 2016 in Digital 3D™ and IMAX® 3D.

Website: Disney.com/TheFinestHours

Facebook: facebook.com/thefinesthoursmovie

©2016 Disney Enterprises, Inc.

results.description:
In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, four times in the year.

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion.

results.description:
Social media is the most influential medium in the world. Not only for marketing, but for employers looking to find you.

If you are a graduating senior in college, or a seasoned professional, this event is for you! We will show you how establish yourself across all forms of social media, so that when you start applying for jobs you will be the first on top of an employer’s list! In this workshop, you'll learn:

▪ Perfecting your LinkedIn profile to attract companies you want to work for


▪ Building a presence on Twitter that establishes you as an expert


▪ Leveraging content channels such as YouTube to stand out


De-stress yourself on finding a job and put your foot in the right direction. We will help guide you on job searching for the New Year! 

About the Instructors:

Jamie Bradley 

     My name is Jamie Bradley. I've been helping clients produce sales and marketing materials since 1984. I became a LinkedIn member in 2007, and have been teaching classes on LinkedIn at the Cambridge Center for Adult Education quarterly since 2013.
     I posted my first blog in 2008, and included a link to in in my work email in hopes of engaging my clients (I was in commission sales) beyond traditional phone calls, visits and emails. Later that year, I decided it was time to start my own thing. I founded Sophwell to help companies streamline how they produce and distribute physical marketing products. Using WordPress, I created my website and began blogging to help build credibility and interest in my company. In 2014 I started using the LinkedIn Posts function. 

Jeff Cutler 

      For 20 years I’ve been assisting people with messaging – and for 17 of those years I’ve run a little company called Novel Ideas. No matter the name – Jeff Cutler or Novel Ideas – I’m all about creating content that inspires and motivates. How did I get here? After a harrowing college career where I dabbled in political science and finance, I emerged with a journalism degree and some healthy skepticism. I worked for New England Sports Network and more big brands than I can remember. Then I realized that life’s about having some fun and I wandered into the fishbowl people call social media.

      Here I swim, creating content, brainstorming strategy, training legions of newcomers and traditional media folks, and having fun. Seriously.

results.description:
THIS IS A PAID EVENT PURCHASE YOUR TICKET HERE

David Rose, Ditto Labs

David Rose is an award-winning entrepreneur, author, and instructor at the MIT Media Lab. His research focuses on making the physical environment an interface to digital information.

David is the CEO atDitto Labs an image-recognition software platform which scours social media photos to find brands and products. His new book, Enchanted Objects, focuses on the future of the internet of things, and how these technologies will impact the ways we live and work.

Prior to Ditto, David founded and was CEO at Vitality, a company that reinvented medication packaging now distributed by CVS, Walgreens, and Express Scripts. He founded Ambient Devices, which pioneered glanceable technology: embedding internet information in everyday objects like lamps, mirrors, and umbrellas.

David holds patents for photo sharing, interactive TV, ambient information displays, and medical devices. His work has been featured at the MoMA, covered in the New York Times, WIRED, and the Economist, and parodied on the Colbert Report.

David co-teaches a popular course in tangible user interfaces at the MIT Media Lab with Hiroshi Ishii. He is a frequent speaker to corporations and design and technology conferences.

He received his BA in Physics from St. Olaf College, studied Interactive Cinema at the MIT Media Lab, and earned a Masters at Harvard.

 

 

Agenda

6:00 Networking and Food
7:00 Fireside Chat
8:00 Networking

Hosted By Carlos Cardenas, Director of Startup Grind Boston

Carlos’ career has focused on exploring the connections between technology, design and the human experience. He is Vice-president of THE MEME, a strategic design consultancy focused on discovering opportunities for innovation and developing human-centered product and service experiences. He has led multi-disciplinary design research projects for diverse organizations including Samsung Electronics, LG, Microsoft, iRobot, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children’s Hospital. He is currently spearheading efforts to develop tools that help bridge the nuances of human-centered qualitative research with agile design practices. Prior to joining THE MEME he was co-founder of CAPO interactive design as well as researcher at Harvard’s Center for Design Informatics.

What is Startup Grind?

Startup Grind is a global startup community designed to educate, inspire, and connect entrepreneurs. We host monthly events in more than 150 cities and 65 countries featuring successful local founders, innovators, educators and investors who share personal stories and lessons learned on the road to building great companies. results.description:
TO ATTEND YOU MUST REGISTER HERE

People often ask me what “the killer app for the IoT” will be. 

There likely won’t be one app to rule them all, but rather an investment in sensor processing technology that combines cognitive computing, deep learning, artificial intelligence, and computational neuroscience in exciting new ways.

The promise of the Internet of Things is WHAT we do with all this time series-based telemetric and contextual data. In this talk, Sean will take a peek under the hood with where predictive analytics is heading with regards to adaptive analyzing time series data in real-time. We’ll be looking at deep learning, more specifically recurrent neural networks, and how they are about to bring environmental awareness to our connected lives.


About Sean Lorenz


Sean Lorenz is Founder & CEO of Senter, a startup improving chronic care with Internet of Things (IoT) and deep learning in the home. He was recently the Director of IoT Market Strategy for LogMeIn’s IoT platform, and has shaped business models and product strategies in several emerging markets including the IoT, robotics, artificial intelligence and healthcare. 

Sean holds a PhD in Cognitive & Neural Systems from Boston University and has extensive knowledge of digital health, natural language processing, brain-computer interfaces, adaptive systems, neuroscience-based computational algorithms, and context-aware computing.


Sponsors:

-Monotype
-AIGA Boston
-Invision
-Media Temple

results.description:
How do we inspire high levels of performance and well-being in ourselves, our colleagues, and our kids? Join positive change author and mentor, Christine Duvivier, as she helps us apply, to our own lives,  leading-edge practices in motivation and inspiration.  

This Evening, You Will ....

...  Explore what the science of positive psychology has to say about motivation and how that relates to ancient wisdom, spirituality and human potential.  Discover why asking, “How do we motivate ourselves, our colleagues, or our kids?” is the wrong question – and what to ask instead to elicit peak performance. Understand external and internal motivators, when to use each, and why they matter. Experience ways to turn on this powerful force for our own success and happiness.

Christine Duvivier will not only overview what is known about motivation, she will lead us in exercises where we can impact our level of motivation.  

Our Leader This Evening

Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, is a leader in the red-hot field of positive psychology. She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands of individuals and groups worldwide, including Fortune 50 executives, individuals, families, and communities. Author of "What I'd Say if You Wouldn't Roll Your Eyes... love notes to my child," Christine mentors and facilitates other professionals-- including leaders, physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors-- using positive approaches to bring out the full potential in themselves and others. Clients say, "Christine helped me become the leader I am... get promoted.... turn problem staff to top performers... engage my team....  get people on board with new strategy and culture.... transform my relationships... see the best in me....feel energized."

She has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. While studying and working with Martin Seligman, David Cooperrider, George Vaillant  and other founders in the science of positive psychology & well-being, she experienced the power of positive change when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience. Her groundbreaking research at UPenn identified paths to unleash hidden gifts and lead each of us to thrive in life.  www.christineduvivier.com

Speaker

Jeremy Deane - Solutions Architect at Liberty Mutual Insurance

Architectural Resiliency

Regardless of the techniques used to make a enterprise solution Highly Available (HA), failure at some point inevitable. Resiliency is how fast a system reacts and then recovers to such failures. This talk will cover a number of techniques and patterns such as Intelligent Agents, Tolerant Reader, and Circuit Breaker, for addressing architectural resiliency.

results.description:
DevOps can be as much about discipline as it is about tools and practices. Management practice for development and deployment must keep pace with the realities of the market and the disruptive technology trends. DevOps has been evolving for the front-line in organizations and in many cases remains in a silo, either within a development group or in IT operations. 

The definition and practice of DevOps must move beyond isolated tools to a cross-organizations management model that links DevOps to the overall performance of the company. In essence, a case needs to be made to go beyond the tools and procedures and create effective management models that aims to optimize performance across business cycles.

Invite senior management from your company to this event!

---

Our panelists are specialists in organizational change, financial management of software technology assets, technology management practices and risk mitigation.

• Callie McDowell – Contributing Editor & Product Strategist @ Change Management Review™ - Change management & organizational development
• Jim Reilly – Managing Director @ Consero Global Solutions LLC – financial executive for tech companies
• Pete Buletza – Managing Director @ Elyxor, Inc. – DevOps in practice
• Kevin Fisher – President @ Dartmouth Research & Consulting – Organizational design, process & operational alignment.

---

Agenda

7:00 - "State-of-Practice for DevOps” - Kevin Fisher
7:30 - Panel introductions
8:00 - Panel discussion + Q&A

Slack Channel:

https://bostondevops.slack.com/messages/meetup_01_21_2016/

We will be polling your questions for our Expert panel from this Slack Channel. Please post any questions you find relevant to the discussion. Sign up for the Boston DevOps Slack group here.

results.description:
For the longest time, making a great experience for the user was a luxury item in a business's strategy. It was a nice-to-have, after identifying a customer need and fulfilling it with a working product. The product had to work and it had to ship. If it was a great experience, well all the better. Times have changed. The cost of creating and delivering a product is no longer a barrier to entry. Quality is no longer a differentiator. What's left? The experience of using the product. If you're going to be truly competitive in today's markets, your products and services better have a great experience. To do that, a fundamental shift has to occur inside your organization. It's no longer acceptable to ship a product with a poor experience or to deliver poor customer service. Every part of the organization has to be infused with an understanding of great user experience. Your organization has to cross the UX Tipping Point. 

BIO
Jared M. Spool is the founder of User Interface Engineering and a co-founder of Center Centre. If you've ever seen Jared speak about user experience design, you know that he's probably the most effective and knowledgeable communicator on the subject today. He's been working in the field of usability and experience design since 1978, before the term "usability" was ever associated with computers.

Jared spends his time working with the research teams at User Interface Engineering, helps clients understand how to solve their design problems, explains to reporters and industry analysts what the current state of design is all about, and is a top-rated speaker at more than 20 conferences every year. With Dr. Leslie Jensen-Inman, he is starting Center Centre, a new school in Chattanooga, TN, to create the next generation of industry-ready UX Designers. In 2014, the school, under the nickname of the Unicorn Institute, launched a Kickstarter project that successfully raised more that 600% of its initial goal. He is also the conference chair and keynote speaker at the annual UI Conference and UX Immersion Conference, and manages to squeeze in a fair amount of writing time. He is author of the book, Web Usability: A Designer's Guide and co-author of Web Anatomy: Interaction Design Frameworks that Work. You can find his writing at uie.com and follow his adventures on the twitters at @jmspool.

VENUE
The meeting will be held in the new meeting auditorium at the Verizon Technology Center. The address is 60 Sylvan Road, Waltham, MA 02451. The entrance is by the far corner - with the picnic tables out front - and not the tower or the new building. It is most easily reached by the West Street entrance.

Admission is free, but Verizon requires us to provide a list of attendees in advance.  If you would like to attend, please register.   

Since we are required to use a registration link outside of Meetup, please do not use the Meetup capability to RSVP.  If it says the event is full, please click on the register link anyway.

We will be taking Jared to dinner at Green Papaya after the talk at about 9pm.

This event is sponsored by GBCACM, the IEEE Computer Society, and BostonCHI.

</a> <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gbcacm.org%2Fseminars%2Fevening%2F2015%2Fbeyond-ux-tipping-point.html&t=Beyond+the+UX+Tipping+Point">

results.description:
Fun with Lego robots and Elixir
by Jean-François Cloutier

Did you know you can program Lego Mindstorms robots using Elixir? As soon as I found out, I got myself a kit and started playing. I wanted to find out if I could use pure functions to control a stateful robot. I also wanted to use concurrent processes to implement a homebrewed robotic "theory of mind". I'll share my journey and my results with you. SPOILER: Elixir/OTP is an awesome platform for robotics.

Lightning Talk - Fuzzy URL
by Peter Gamache

Fuzzyurl is a library for non-strict parsing, construction, and fuzzy-matching of URLs.

The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

Sweating the Small Stuff: The Fun and Fear of Near-Earth Asteroids


Jose-Luis Galache, CfA

The explosion of an asteroid over Russia in 2013 caught by hundreds of dashcams, and the perennial reminder of the dinosaurs' demise due to an earlier, and bigger, asteroid impact, serve to illustrate the fear that asteroids may inspire in us. But near-Earth asteroids, our closest neighbors in the Solar System, also offer hitherto unimagined opportunities for exploration and resource harvesting. They might even be the stepping stones we require to seed the solar system with space colonies. The International Astronomical Union's Minor Planet Center, located at the CfA, is on the front line of asteroid discoveries and is vital to the research of asteroid scientists the world over. We'll explore its inner workings and how it contributes to both the fun and fear of near-Earth asteroids.


******************************

NOTE: if anyone would like to be an assistant organizer to help run various* events please contact me - Heather

*various = various science and nerdy events around town, and NOT the ones that only market your own event/product.  (SPAM=no)

The waiting list and attendance limit is for the CfA to have a more accurate attendance count.

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

H

results.description:
Energy is the bridge between mind and body, inside and outside, Self and Source.  Our bodies are designed to perceive energy through our emotions and other body-based sensations. 

Love, happiness, joy, peace and pleasure reflect the healthy flow of energy.  Sadness, fear, anger, emotional pain and suffering are calls for help from the energy body.   They reflect dysfunctional energy patterns such as blocks and reversals.

Blocked energy causes a build up of pressure and "hardening" of the energy.  The harder the energy, the more uncomfortable.  Energy is blocked by thought, habit, and reaction patterns in the energy field.  Blocked energy can be unblocked for healing and renewed receptivity to the juicy, healthy and pleasurable energies of life.

We help energy flow by welcoming, encouraging, supporting and intending our energy to soften, flow, and move in, through, and out of the body. 

This very direct process of gently dissolving, flowing and releasing energy to recover the healthy, natural flow is taught in a system called EmoTrance.  

To learn more, go to www.emotrance.com.   You can sign up with them to receive free downloads.

We will continue to review and practice other important energy self-care techniques to help us all ground, center and align our energies for learning, emotional well-being, health and optimal performance.

Thanks!

results.description:
Want your intention and resolution setting to be different this year?
More powerful, meaningful, long lasting? 

Join us for an inspiring opportunity to transform your relationship to the whole New Year Resolution thing - a re-frame of the what, how and why of your goals and ambitions.

This month in our MetroCharles Heartbeat Salon...

- Are you a new year resolutions maker? 
- Does goal setting feel inspiring to you or does it feel more like ‘shoulds’?
- Do you like the idea of having intentions but get disenchanted with how they lose steam after a while?

Whatever your relationship to goal setting, one thing tends to be a powerful truth behind it for all of us - it’s never really the goal itself we’re chasing. What we’re chasing is a feeling.

When we go after the stuff we want to accomplish, have, do, experience - we hope, yearn, pray that we’ll be fulfilled when we get there. We want it to make us feel good. And sometimes it does. But plenty of times it doesn’t. 

Why? because many times we’ve got the process upside down. 

Having an outside-in approach (focusing on the what and the how in our goal setting in order to get to our why) is backwards. And that approach is what can have us feeling the ’shoulds’ and losing steam every year.

What if, first, we got powerfully clear on how we actually wanted to feel in our life, and then we laid out our intentions? 

What if your most desired feelings consciously informed how you plan your day, your year, your career, your holidays — your life? 

If you really knew what your core desired feelings were, and could learn to powerfully use them as a guidance tool, your inner GPS...

• Would decisions be easier to make? 
• Would you be tuned in to exactly when you want to say no, and what you want to say hell yes! to?
• Would your goals have more soul?
• Would your resolutions finally resonate?
• Would you be able to keep your motivation throughout the year?

Knowing how you want to feel is the most potent clarity you can have. Generating those feelings through your intentional actions is a powerful way to live your life!

In this workshop certified wellness coach, Katrina Piehler will introduce us to some of Danielle LaPorte’s powerful Desire Map work as a model for deeply re-framing how we relate to intention setting and goal planning in our lives.


To prepare for this evening... 

Before our gathering, give some thought to these questions:

• How do you feel about goal or resolution setting?

• How do you want to feel about it?

• Do you remember a time when you set a goal and it:

- flat out failed?
- you decided to make a mid-course correction, and it worked out (or it bombed)
- the goal happened later than you intended?
- you super exceeded the goal?

Our Leader This Evening...

Katrina Piehler is a PGN organizer and a certified Wellness Coach, Bodyworker & Licensed Desire Map Facilitator. Positive psychology and the law of attraction are foundational concepts that both guide her personal life and inform her work. 

In 2003 she founded Living from Center- a massage therapy and wellness coaching practice whose mission is to help busy people shift from feeling stressed out and discontented in their lives --to feeling re-connected to vitality, tuned in to their own wisdom, & empowered to create lives they love living! 

Links


For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon? 
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Veterans: 
  * Find a Heartbeat Salon Near You . 
  * Calendar of Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 

For Hosts: 
  * Hints on How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics from Past Heartbeat Salons .

For Presenters: 
  * Hints on How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Suggestion Box: 
  * Suggestions for a Heartbeat Salon (topics, locations, etc) .

Address:
Uno Due Go is located at 52 Summer St., Boston MA 02110 USA.

Date and time:
Thursday, January 21st, 2016 from 7pm to 8:30pm (or later if we decide to go somewhere else after).


Public Transportation:
It is located in downtown Boston, on the corner of Summer Street and Arch Street, across from the Macy's and CVS at Downtown Crossing T [Boston subway] station (Red Line and Orange Line). It is a 5-minute walk from South Station (various T, bus, and train connections), a 5-minute walk from Park Street T Station (Green Line), and a 7-minute walk from State Street T Station (Blue Line).

Parking:
There are parking meters on the street, where you can park for up to 4 hours. Then, they are free after 8pm. After that, parking is free. There is also a paid parking lot a few blocks away at 100 Federal Street, across from the Bank of America building between Franklin Street and Matthew Street. After 5pm, the cost is $10 flat for the day.

Let me know if there are any other questions. See you then!

results.description: Come check out dragon boating with Living Root! We're a co-ed dragon boat team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, stay in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive. How to get there: We practice at the pool at the JFK Elementary School in Somerville. Walk through the outdoor basketball courts to the rear of the building to find the pool entrance. Take the stairs down to the ground floor and head through the locker rooms to get to the pool. Practice will begin poolside at 7 pm. Wear athletic clothing. Although we won't do any swimming, you will get somewhat wet. Parking is free in the school parking lot. The T station at Porter Square is a 5 minute walk away. Practice will last an hour and 45 minutes. We provide paddles and all the necessary equipment--just bring yourself! No paddling experience is required. We have an excellent coaching staff who will teach you everything you will need to know. We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us. Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked] [url=http://www.livingroot.org/]www.livingroot.org[/url]

Iconic fighting style of many cultures the sword and shield have been in use for centuries. This class teaches the fundamentals of using a single-handed sword and combining that with a shield.

The Common program is appropriate for Viking, Medieval and Highland Scots methods of fighting with the Sword & Shield.

The program is developed from primarily 18th century sources such as Thomas Page. As well as from the modern work of Christopher Scott Thompson.

The program starts with development of carrying out basic skills plus the buckler and grows towards advanced buckler specific techniques.

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 6.25% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.

results.description:
Please RSVP!  Note that the room is 149 on the first floor of E51.  We will try to move it to a more spacious room on the third floor.  I will put up signs if there is a last minute change of room.

Market Outlook for 2016

By Phil Erlanger, CMT

Please RSVP!!!  Map and parking info at bottom of announcement.

  Phil Erlanger will present his technical view of the market charts, as well as sectors and selected stocks.  He’ll briefly discuss their methodology, including the role that sentiment, seasonality and other technical indicators play in a bias, setup and trigger strategy. 

   Using short interest data, he graded individual stocks by the success rate of their short sellers.  He aligned portfolios taking into account the relative intensity of short sellers, parsing the “smart” short sellers from the “dumb” short sellers.  These data were extrapolated to sectors and the market as a whole with what we call the Erlanger Commitment of Short Sellers (ECOS) indicator.

About the speaker:

Phil Erlanger is the President of Phil Erlanger Research, which has provided research to institutions since the early 1990s. Previously, Phil was the Senior Technical Analyst for Fidelity Management & Research. He came to Fidelity from Advest where he was the Chief Technical Analyst through most of the 1980s.

Phil has developed Erlanger Chart Room, a technical analysis platform that focuses on advanced technical indicators that include in depth sentiment and seasonal studies. This platform runs as a stand-alone EOD service, and in real-time on eSignal and Bloomberg. Phil has also developed the www.goodmorningwallst.com educational and research series that include videos teaching the use of technical analysis in the real world.

Twice Phil was a past president of the Market Technicians Association. In 1997, Mr. Erlanger won the MTA Best of the Best Award for Computer Assisted Analysis.

He has lectured at Universities including Rutgers, MIT, Boston University, Howard University, and Emory and as an adjunct Professor at Bentley College where he taught a Technical Analysis course. He graduated from Boston University with an economics degree.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

MIT Building 51, Room 149  map ->  http://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E51

70 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA (Entrance at 2 Amherst Street)

(Parking behind the building, or one block West off Amherst Street)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have a friend you talk stocks with, bring them with you! Food or drinks are not allowed in any MIT meeting room. We strongly urge each person to make his or her own decisions about investing their money. Investment ideas and recommendations made during our meetings and in our online dialogs bear no liability by anyone. This is a free and open meeting. No membership is required, but please RSVP.
results.name: Special Speakers Meeting: Phil Erlanger

results.description:
This Thursday 1/21 Sunset Grill and Tap is hosting Victory Brewing as we celebrate their 20th Anniversary! Victory is bringing 10 delicious beers to try, including a super rare Java Cask (one of only two kegs in the state). There will also be a chance to win unique prizes, and of course, SWAG! 

Try the rich and complex Java Cask, a barrel aged stout that clocks in at 14% ABV. This tasty brew has an inviting blend of sweet bourbon and oak with a complex fusion of dark chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. We are going to have one of only TWO kegs in all of New England!

The Blackboard Agave IPA is the pilot beer of Victory's "blackboard" series. This crisp IPA is mixed with a touch of agave syrup and grapefruit juice, giving it a great hop aroma and a slight citrus bite! 

Marcus from Victory will also be on site to talk shop, answer questions, and host a FREE raffle with some sweet Victory Brewing prizes! 

There are a ton more Victory Beers on tap (and they have flights!), so come down to Sunset and have a few delicious Victory Brews. Don't forget to RSVP!

Sorry for any confusion about RSVP'ing on the meetup page. I'm in the middle of a meetup learning curve...trying to figure it out.

----

An evening of getting to know a whole bunch of eligible people without the time limit and interview style of speed dating. There will be many opportunities to interact and connect and get to know each other in ways that are more similar to a second or third date. Opportunities to get real and have fun and really get a sense of someone in a way that isn’t often available in a very short conversation.

Like speed dating you will be able to privately indicate if you are interested in someone. And after the event you will get a list of matches. But there will be many opportunities to feel out who’s a match. Many varying opportunities to really get a sense of someone that is usually not there in a 7 minute conversation.

This will also just be a fun social gathering. Plenty of time just to hang out and connect. Wine and appatizers will be provided. 

Facilitated by Katie Greenman, M.A. founder of HumanSide and The Social Beings Project.Katie has a masters in Human Development, is a Certified Coach, Comedy School Graduate and founder of HumanSide (a value-driven consulting firm that designs and delivers experiential programs

A prepaid ticket is required in order to monitor gender-balance 

Click HERE to purchase your ticket. There will be NO ticket sales at the door.

Click here to join our mailing list for future events.

Please note: when you check out it says "Pay with PayPal" but you don't need to have paypal account and can use any major credit card. 

The make sure that you don't miss any of the Speed Dating SLOWLY events click here to join a new meetup group  Boston Dating Success  

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/Successful-Online-Dating-in-Boston/"></a>

You are invited to join us at an Essential Oil 101 classes designed to help us meet our New Year's Promises & Intentions when it comes to our health goals.
In these hands-on workshops, you’ll experience first-hand how amazing essential oils are and how beneficial they are for your health & wellness! We'll share how pure therapeutic grade essential oils can be part of your daily health habits and how they fit seamlessly into your healthy lifestyle.


Each workshop is a free educational event.

Bring your goals with you!


We look forward to sharing information and some time with you.

If you are new to Young Living Therapeutic Grade Essential Oils, this is a great introduction. If you are an oiler already, this workshop is a great introduction for your family and friends, feel free to bring them along! e do not diagnose, prescribe, treat or cure.


You don't have to come alone! 


~Bring 1 friend and receive a special oil infused gift! 


~ Bring 2 friends and go home with a bottle of essential oil!

~ Bring 3 friends and go home with a bottle of Ningxia Red!

*You do not need to be a BAC member to attend. But, you must RSVP so we can plan for hand outs, snacks and supplies for our make and take.*

results.description:
Come and learn how to sustain your weight loss.

Your weight did not go up overnight (unless you had a metabolic disease) and it won’t come off in a sustainable fashion overnight either. Sure you can decrease calories dramatically and notice a change, but you will lose muscle and fat if you “starve” yourself and it won’t stay off for the long run.


The worst part is that when you gain it back it is 100% fat and when you lost the weight, only 80% was fat and 20% of it was precious muscle. Learn how to stop these yo-yo weight fluctuations that degrade your body composition and make you fatter with each cycle of weight loss and weight gain.


Learn why this is so important to your health for the long term dramatically. Seating is limited so please register here; https://welleffect.com/events/

results.description:
Events for the Public

The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics sponsors a variety of free programs for the public. Among these events are Observatory Nights held on the third Thursday of the month (excluding June, July and August). Observatory Nights feature a nontechnical lecture and telescopic observing from the observatory roof if weather permits. The lectures are intended for high-school age and older audiences but children are also welcome. We also sponsor a variety of other special astronomical events throughout the year. No reservations are necessary, but seating is limited to the auditorium's capacity. Admission is free.

These events--unless otherwise noted--are held in Phillips Auditorium (at the rear of the CfA complex near Madison Street and large parking lot), 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, about 1 mile west of Harvard Square. Parking lots marked for Observatory Staff are open to the public on event nights. Parking is free.

The Observatory does not host private events.

Monthly Observatory Night
Thursday, January 21, 2016
7:30 pm: Sweating the Small Stuff: The Fun and Fear of Near-Earth Asteroids


Jose-Luis Galache, CfA


The explosion of an asteroid over Russia in 2013 caught by hundreds of dashcams, and the perennial reminder of the dinosaurs' demise due to an earlier, and bigger, asteroid impact, serve to illustrate the fear that asteroids may inspire in us. But near-Earth asteroids, our closest neighbors in the Solar System, also offer hitherto unimagined opportunities for exploration and resource harvesting. They might even be the stepping stones we require to seed the solar system with space colonies. The International Astronomical Union's Minor Planet Center, located at the CfA, is on the front line of asteroid discoveries and is vital to the research of asteroid scientists the world over. We'll explore its inner workings and how it contributes to both the fun and fear of near-Earth asteroids.

For more information, including accessibility, or to sign up for the events mailing list, call the Public Affairs Office, (617)[masked] or email [masked]. Please request sign-language interpretation at least 2 weeks before the event. Current sky information is available.

Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."

Source(s): http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/publicevents

Also available via their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ObsNights
results.name: Sweating the Small Stuff: The Fun and Fear - Monthly Observatory Night

• Do you feel overwhelmed, anxious, worried or stressed-out too much of the time?

• Do you feel unable to feel joy most of your day?


Come to experience states of deep relaxation and inner calm, and to learn how meditation can serve you in bringing more ease and joy into your life.  And, I  always make it easy for you!


Each time we meet, we will have 3 guided meditations along with tips and discussion to help you release your cause of stress, and to build and reinforce positive thinking patterns that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy (even when you're not meditating!).


• This is a 4 week series so you can more fully make a true difference in your life.  ($70 for the 4 sessions /or 5 if you include the free one on the 14th!) The series will run Thursday evenings, from Jan. 21st  - Feb. 11. 

Advanced sign-up and payment through this link is required:   https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=219504&stype=-8&sView=week&sTrn=100000013

• If you have questions, e-mail her at [masked].

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class to deepen your learning, and to help you carry the positive feelings, insights and lessons experienced into your day and life.

“Ann's guided meditation class is like a mini-relaxation get-away. It was not only relaxing, but also heart-warming and very inspiring. I walked away feeling much more at peace and content than an hour earlier; and with a few good new tricks up my sleeve for meditation practice. I would recommend this class to anyone that wants to just plain enjoy life more.” Nancy

“I just want to comment on your meditation: Awesome! I was really stressed out today, worried mostly about job and home hunting. This helped me to calm down and feel at peace within the first few minutes. Thanks! ” Melissa

“I am leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, and full of love. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned in your class will help me very much. Thank you!!!” Julia

“Ann was wonderful! I came into the room after the rush of the day and was immediately at peace. Her calm, focused and patient nature was so welcoming. I am still using the techniques taught in the class.” Linda

“In the world we live today, the peace, relaxation, and happiness that come with Ann's techniques are not to be missed.”

results.description:
BOSTON BEEKEEPERS' BEE SCHOOL

*First class is Thursday, January 21st (pre-register today to ensure your space in the course)*

In this 6-session course we will cover basic techniques of "organic" beekeeping, including materials and equipment, beehive structure, the life cycle of bees, hive development and dynamics, seasonal apiary work, honey and hive products, common pests and diseases, and hive management - with an emphasis on treatment-free and ecologically-friendly management techniques. We will taste local and varietal honeys, and learn about harvesting and using bee products. You will learn everything you need to know to set up your own backyard apiary!


DATES & TIMES: Six Thursday evenings Jan-March from 7:30-9:00pm (see below for exact dates and times). There will also be a hands-on field date in April, date TBD based on weather & bees' activity. 
1/21 from 7:30-9:00pm
1/28 from 7:00-9:00pm *note early start time (regular end time)
2/11 from 7:30-9:00pm
2/25 from 7:30-9:00pm
3/10 from 7:30-9:00pm
3/17 from 7:30-9:00pm
(3/24 = backup/snow date)
4/?? Apiary date in April TBD

LOCATION: Urbano Project, 29 Germania Street, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130 (located in the Brewery complex on Amory Street, across from Stony Brook T Stop)

Space and time to enroll is limited! CLICK HERE TO REGISTER TODAY! Pre-registration highly recommended (space may fill up and only those pre-registered will be guaranteed a seat).

Cost: $165 
** COURSE FEE ALSO INCLUDES A HANDS-ON WORKSHOP ON A DATE TBD IN APRIL 

SCHOLARSHIPS: Limited scholarships are available to interested individuals experiencing financial hardship. If you are interested in a scholarship, please send an email describing your circumstances to [masked] and we will be in touch!

Course books will be provided on the day of the class, for an additional $10.

Course instructors: The course will be taught by members of Boston Area Beekeepers Association (www.bostonbeekeepers.org). This year's instructors include Rachael Bonoan, Noah Wilson-Rich, Paul Quigley, Dave Strickler, Mel Gadd, Bill Perkins and other experienced local beekeepers. For more on our organizing team & core instructors please visit: http://www.bostonbeekeepers.org/membership/board-directors/.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Hi Boston Social Tennis Leaguers!

Hope you've all been able to play a lot of tennis in this warm start to the winter!

If not, I have some good news: We'll be holding one-day ‘play day’ events at the Boston Athletic Club (BAC location linked) from 7:30 to 10:00 p.m. on these four dates:
1) Thursday, January 21st
2) Thursday, February 18th
3) Thursday, March 17th
4) Thursday, April 14th

How it'll work: We'll have access to four courts: three for abbreviated matches and one repurposed for Can-Jam, Spikeball, Ladderball, and Cornhole… and, of course, prizes for winners. After we play, we'll also have access to the BAC’s on-site bar and restaurant.
Interested in getting on the court again this winter? 

How to Register

1. Click here to register on TennisLink.  Register for each session individually or sign up for all four to save! Each individual session costs $18. The four-session package costs $50 ($72 value). With any questions or concerns, email Christo Schultz.

2. Enter the “team number” for the night you want to play and then click enter:

  Thursday, January 21st - [masked]

  Thursday, February 18th - [masked]

  Thursday, March 17th - [masked]

  Thursday, April 14th – [masked]

  All 4 events package deal - [masked]

3. Enter your team tennis ID number or membership number. If you don't have an ID number, click Sign Up as a Non-Member. You will receive an email with a team tennis ID number.

4. Proceed to checkout and pay the registration fee.

You are NOT required to sign up for a USTA Membership to join the league.

The team tennis ID number is a free account that gives you access to registration, the league schedule, stats and upcoming matches and more.

Thanks everyone! We look forward to seeing you there—and don’t forget to mark those dates down on your calendars!

Christo

Mike Lemme and  Chris Post present this monthly showcase featuring talented comedians, musicians and poets inside one of Cambridge's most unique venues, Gallery263. The name, Off Mic! refers to the fact that Gallery 263 is so intimate, amplification is often totally unnecessary. Without a microphone, the barrier between performer and audience is knocked down. Off-Mic! gives audience members a behind-the-scenes look at the creative process of performing. TICKETS: Suggested donation of $10 at the door

This week features performances by  Shaun Bedgood, Jordan Handren-Seavey, Kate Procyshyn, and Billy McShane.

results.description:
Sean Patton (Comedy Central, @Midnight, Inside Amy Schumer, Conan, etc.) headlines this month's edition of Strange Behavior, a stand-up comedy show hosted by Ryan Donahue at the historic Davis Square Theatre. Featuring NYC's Doug Smith, as seen at the Just For Laughs Festival in Montreal!

Tix and info: http://bit.ly/1PtmNNI

Sean Patton Bio: Hello, my name is Sean Patton. I’m a comedian based in Los Angeles and New York, by way of New Orleans. I began doing stand-up in the Crescent City and have since performed in comedy clubs across the US and Canada. I’ve also performed at The Melbourne International Comedy Festival (2011), Just for Laughs Chicago (2013), Just for Laughs Toronto (2013), and Just for Laughs Montreal (2008, 2010, 2012). I’ve performed on Comedy Central’s Live at Gotham (2009), Late Night with Jimmy Fallon (2010), and Conan (2011, 2013). 2013 also marked the release of my Comedy Central Half Hour.

More recently, I’ve been on @midnight (2014, 2015) and will be on the second seasons of The Meltdown with Jonah and Kumail (2015) andThis Is Not Happening (2015). As for acting, I've appeared on IFC'S Maron and Comedy Central's Inside Amy Schumer. Those are the things I’ve done that I’m proud of. For a list of things I’ve done that I’m not so proud of... yeah right, you ain’t never gonna know that! I love what I do, some of you will too (thanks!), and some of you will not (but thanks for coming). I want to share myself with you, whomever you are.

"I’ve seen him perform more than a dozen sets, and he’s killed every time. He’s dynamite, even with ordinary material, turning standard Brooklyn hipster jokes into a stomping, roaring tour de force, and elevating a bit about sex-performance anxiety into high-stakes comedy. [...] He’s the rare comic who goes over as well in a comedy club as in a bar basement." - New York Times
results.name: Strange Behavior @ Davis Square Theatre

results.description:
--->NOTE: This is a FREE DIGITAL EVENT at your location on your device where-ever you are! Requires registration & gotowebinar download to attend. 

REGISTER NOW: http://bit.ly/1P4u9sx

We've been told how important it is to get closer to our customers and to conduct market research in order to inform business decisions with real data about those customers. Reliability, validity, and accuracy of that data is of vital importance. There are some real challenges anytime we interact with people in the hopes of understanding their beliefs, values, and opinions of our products. Often our own words and behaviors can affect another person's responses. In addition, those people are also under the influence of their own psycho/social/biological/cultural history and frameworks. So how can we gather information without inadvertently skewing the outcome? How do we even know if/when that has happened? What pitfalls do we need to avoid when dealing with these complex humans we call customers? 

Join us for this webinar hosted by Paula Gray, AIPMM Anthropologist, where we will step back and gain a better understanding of human behavior in general so we can move forward and use that information to our competitive advantage. Whether you use this knowledge in visits with customers, creating survey questions or leading a focus group, it will help you get the best possible (most accurate) data in those interactions. 

Topics covered will include: 

- The best time of day to conduct an interview or focus group 

- How to be as physically neutral as possible in person so your presence doesn't affect respondent answers 

- How to phrase questions to avoid bias 

- The truth about inaccurate answers - intentional or unintentional by the respondent
results.name: Webcast: 4 Tips To Get The Most Out Of Market Research

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Please join EMC for the grand opening of the first EMC-Pivotal Cloud Foundry dojo in the heart of the Cambridge tech hub.

WHAT:

This EMC-hosted cocktail party is an opportunity to meet the Cloud Foundry Community and to celebrate the opening of the joint EMC-Pivotal Cloud Foundry Dojo.

WHEN:

Fri., Jan. 22 from 2:00 – 4:00 pm

WHERE:

EMC offices – 11 Cambridge Center (145 Broadway), Cambridge, MA

WHO:

Please join the Cloud Foundry Foundation CEO Sam Ramji, Cloud Foundry Chairman of the Board John Roese, EMC President Brian Gallagher, Cloud Foundry developers, partners, customers, press and analysts

BACKGROUND:

It can typically take upwards of a year for a developer to gain committer status on an open source project. In some cases, even longer. The Cloud Foundry Foundation offers a unique approach to gaining committer in as little as six weeks, which we call the Cloud Foundry Dojo. The program is derived from the Pivotal labs Dojo program. It allows developers to master Cloud Foundry by working shoulder to shoulder on the open-source project with other Cloud Foundry engineers. Qualified engineers from the Cloud Foundry community can participate in pair programming with committers on a Cloud Foundry project team, gain invaluable experience with the core technology and the unique agile development environment, and make direct contributions to the codebase. Participation typically lasts 6-12 weeks.

·  Become part of the EMC Cloud Foundry Technical Community

·  Learn DevOps practices and culture

·  Accelerate your knowledge of the Cloud Foundry platform

·   Develop relationships with all the key contributors

·  Lead the next wave of innovation

EMC's Cambridge-based Dojo will host software developers from EMC customers and partners, along with developers from EMC's own software engineering ranks. The facility itself is designed as an open shared environment that is purpose-built for software developers to write code together through the agile pair programming/TDD model. The facility will also host regular Meetups with the local Cloud Foundry community.

Please RSVP by Signing up for the Meetup
