results.description:
Good news...looks like the snowstorm  is going to be to the south of us and we are not going to get slammed.   Yeah!   We are going to the 7PM show.  I will be at the theater by 6.  The theater should let us upstairs by 6:15, where we will gather at the tables by the big window.  We will head in for seats around 6:30. Tickets are on sale now on Fandango.

Evil aliens come to take the planet and kill the all the humans in the process....they didn't bargain for just how ornery and lethal humans can be though.   Somehow I think they may have bitten off more than they can chew!

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away?  Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process?   Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome.  Do you have a cribbage board?  If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before?  The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham.  Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

results.description:
We will practice together, play and study theory.

Usually we get quite a few beginners, so if you are just starting don't be shy, you definitely can join us. If you have been playing for some time I am sure you will find a few helpful ideas as well. If the level will be very different then we might divide it to two groups eventually.

Half of the class time is dedicated to a consecutive curriculum. We try to choose themes that are relevant to everybody in the class. We might talk about some aspects of technique, or reading, or theory etc. The other half of the class time we usually help students with their individual issues and questions.

We see this class as a supportive and motivational environment for your self-teaching process. There are two experienced guitar teachers (Anastasiya Dumma and David Lee), both Berklee grads, who are ready to answer all your questions and suggest new things to practice!

This is PAY-WHAT-YOU-WANT class. We kindly ask you to support your teachers and Westland Guitars that provided the space. Online donations feel a bit inconvenient (sorry), so you can contribute when you come to the class.

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!

results.description:
This month we will be exploring Shiraz and possibly some other wines from McLaren Valley Australia.


McLaren Valley is the birthplace of the South Australian wine industry and home to some of the world’s oldest grape vines. It's Mediterranean climate has created ideal conditions for grape-growing. Shiraz is the most important variety grown in the region, accounting for about half of the area's production. You can find more information at the following site: http://www.australia.com/en/places/sa/mclaren-vale.html

Here's the line up of what we will be tasting:


D'Arenberg The Hermit Crab Viogner 2013 (Greeting wine)

D'Arenberg The Stump Jump Shiraz 2011

Thomas Goss Shiraz 2013

D'Arenberg The Football Shiraz 2012

Hugh Hamilton The Rascal Shiraz 2012

Two Hands Gnarly Dudes Shiraz 2013

Mitolo Jester Shiraz 2013

The cost will be approx $20/person depending on how many people come.  Please bring an appetizer to share.
results.name: McLaren Valley Australia

group.name: Wine Tasting Acton,MA. American Wine Society Chapter.

results.description:
The Framingham Drum Circle will now only meet with a minimum of 14 YES rsvp's. Join us for a high energy, fun evening to celebrate drumming, community, dance. Fine for beginners as well as experts. We're in a great space with lots of room for dancers - so come and try both drumming and dance if you wish. Bring friends, extra drums to share, maybe some snacks. MINI-CLASS at 6:30 sharp. A good introduction for beginners, and a tune-up for experts.

Admission $10   children under 12 Free

If you never drummed - welcome - we make it easy, and have drums to share.

Please log in to meetup group and "RSVP" so we know how many are coming, and how many drums to bring.

If you have NOT filled out the "bio" questions, please do so by logging in at Meetup group and editing the "profile", where you can let us know if you have a drum, or need one.

THANKS!!

John & Andra & Alan & Fanta
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is from parking lot behind the church. If lost call me at 617-967-2962  - John Tracy

Way Up South returns to JJs Sports bar for a hometown show to celebrate their two year anniversary as a band with us! Way Up South is a northern band (Northboro) with deep southern rock roots. Way Up South's music goes in directions and to places beyond the Southern Rock or Jam Band genres, and has earned them the right to call their music "Big Sky" sound, which is the name of their new CD.

If you have never been to JJ's it is absolutely worth the trip. Big stage, big dance floor and plenty of seats! They have a great sound system, a friendly staff and great wings!! See you there!

results.description:
Breast cancer affects women of all ages and sexual orientations.  The Massachusetts Breast Cancer Coalition's (MBCC) goal is prevention.  (For info about the MBCC and its mission, go to their website: http://mbcc.org/breast-cancer-prevention/about/ )

This year they are holding the 18th Annual Lesbians and Friends Party for Prevention, an annual fundraiser ($40 in advance, $45 at the door), on Saturday, January 23.

All women of all orientations are welcome.  It is a fun and high-energy event for a wonderful cause.  In addition to dancing, complimentary hors d'oeuvres, and a cash bar, there is a silent auction.

Here is the invitation from Cheryl Osimo, Executive Director of the MBCC:

Dear Friend,

The New Year is soon approaching and that means it's almost time for the first great party of 2016!

The 18th Annual Lesbians and Friends Dance: A Party for Prevention is the premier LGBTQA party in Massachusetts, hosted by Massachusetts Breast Cancer Coalition (MBCC). The dance benefits MBCC's work towards preventing environmental causes of breast cancer through community education, research advocacy, and changes to public policy.

New for this year!

MBCC will be hosting an online auction prior to the event so you can pre-bid on some of our unique auction items in advance, including art work, jewelry and a weekend getaway. This online auction will be extended to an in-person silent auction on the day of the dance. For more information and to start bidding please visit <a>http://www.biddingOwl.com/MBCC</a>;.


Dance tickets are only $40 when purchased in advance. Tickets are $45 at the door on the day of the event. More information can be found at <a>www.mbcc.org</a>.
results.how_to_find_us: I will try to secure us a table and put our Meetup sign on the table.
results.name: MBCC's Party for Prevention -- 18th Annual Lesbians and Friends Dance

group.name: Embracing Your Power and Passion after 50

The 18th annual Lesbians & Friends Dance will be held again by the Massachusetts Breast Cancer Coalition on Saturday, January 23, 2016 from 8:30 PM to 12:30 AM at the Holiday Inn Brookline located on 1200 Beacon Street in Brookline, MA. Join for a free one-hour dance workshop, music from DJ Jodi, a silent auction, complimentary hors d’oevres, and a cash bar. Tickets are $40 in advance and can be purchased through paypal and $45 at the door on the day of the event.  For more information, please visit www.mbcc.org or call [masked]-6222. All proceeds benefit breast cancer prevention.
results.name: MBCC Party for the Prevention

results.description:
There may be a big snowstorm coming our way this weekend but theres always a blizzard of comedic proportions on stage at Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy, THE MENDOZA LINE!

This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS! With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful and quality laughs!

Buy your tix now to guarantee a seat as spaces are limited. We've had two straight weeks of sell outs and we'd hate to turn you away Doris

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114

This week's show features the comedic talents of:

CASEY MALONE (Fine Line Comedy)

KENICE MOBLEY (Boston Comedy Festival)

JIAYONG LI (MIT Comedy Night)

JORDAN HANDREN-SEAVEY (winner, Beantown Comedy Riots)

GARY PETERSEN (Great American Comedy Festival)

AND MORE! COME!

No guests are permitted on Boston Area Photography Group events. Please have your guests join our Meetup. 

MEETUP DESCRIPTION: Lets get out and capture the new snow with minimal foot prints. We will have heavy cloud cover so we will focus on capturing details within the garden rather than landscape shots.

NOTE the weather forecast has changed, do not know if I will be able to get out of my driveway tomorrow morning... changing to self-led - hope to join you.

GEAR/CLOTHING/FOOTWARE SUGGESTIONS: Dress in layers as it will be cold with 11mph winds with gusts to 20mph, one lens so you don't have to change out and deal with fog, tripod with means of attaching your bag for stability,  warm boots, micro spikes or yak traks

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
It's my birthday, help me celebrate!

This is a multiple Group event and our 4th or 5th year. There are already 20+ signed up in the South Shore group. This really is a blast for everyone. I hope to see you there. 

Date subject to change because of the weather. 

The line gets long at 9:00 am so get there earlier if you can.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0dG1TkbqQ8

Snow Tubing with lots of Hot Chocolate & whip cream!

Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow......

This is ALWAYS a fun event! Let's get together and tube. Fun for all ages, no expertise level involved :-)

We can get a group discount with 15 or more people, and we call ahead to book it with them. The regular rate is $30/2 hrs, group rate is $28/3 hrs. You CAN'T http://www.skinashoba.com/tubing.html

Tickets are good for exactly 3 hours, so even if you show up at 10 AM, you still have 3 hours to hit the snow lanes.

If Mother Nature doesn't cooperate, we can <a>schedule</a> a different date.

SOME SPECIFICS:

- Minimum requirements are 42" in height or 6 years old to participate.

- One person per tube. Doubles or group tubing may be allowed based on conditions.

- Please note that warmer weather or fresh snow (man-made or natural) make for slower tubing conditions! The colder and more compact the snow is the faster we go down the hill!

- In order to get the <a>Group Rates</a> we have to purchase the <a>tickets </a>at the same time - so please don't be late.

- Roger will send out his <a>phone number</a> a few days before.

FYI - the Tubing park is NOT in the same area as the ski resort, so go to the address listed above.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Matt's white Nissan Altima or Roger's white Toyota Sienna minivan (and if its not too windy his blue 10x10 canopy) between 8:30 and 9:00 am.
results.name: Snow Tubing @ Nashoba Valley!

results.description:
We'll start across from the Stone zoo & hike he Crystal Spring Tr., The Virginia Woods Tr. & a little of the Rock Circuit Tr.  before looping back!  Approx.  7 mi. Hiking Time Approx. 3.5 Hrs.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up. 

Please note this is not a beginners’ hike. It is for intermediate level hikers and beginning hikers who keep in fit condition doing other things. You should be in good enough physical condition to keep up and stay with the group going at a moderate pace. Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared.Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme temperature cancels.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be driving a tan Chevy Impala
results.name: Eastern Middlesex Fells Hike

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.

This week we will again try to connect HH to a new trail on Northfield Road.  This is approx 4.5 - 5 miles round trip and takes just about an 2  1/2 hours. We are definitely getting closer to finding the connection.  It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg Hike over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots. Sneakers are OK, however we do encounter streams from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind. Poles are acceptabe as well. Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:30 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

From Ancient Greek predecessors, through Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill, to contemporary philosophers, utilitarianism has had a profound effect on modern moral theory, and especially secular ethics. In this presentation, Desmond Ravenstone reviews the history, principles, problems and evolution of this influential school of thought.

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 


Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs

Reality is known through reason

Meaning comes from making a difference

Human hands solve human problems

Be accepting, and be accepted


Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.
results.name: Sunday Gathering-Desmond Ravenstone-Doing Our Best: The Legacy of Utilitarianism

results.description:
Meet in the visitor center parking lot then walk along the historic trail.  

 MINUTE MAN NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK is located 22 miles outside of Boston within the towns of Lexington, Lincoln and Concord. The park commemorates the opening battles of the American Revolution on April 19, 1775 by protecting, preserving and interpreting the significant historic sites, structures, landscapes, events and ideas embodied by these events. This five mile trail connects historic sites from Meriam's Corner in Concord to the eastern boundary of the park in Lexington.  

GETTING THERE From I-95: Take exit 30B to Route 2A west. Continue west on 2A for a half mile. http://www.nps.gov/mima/planyourvisit/upload/MIMA%20Park%20Map.pdf

results.description:
Past Lives, Present Lessons

“Everything that we have today––from our preference in clothing to our position in the family where we happened to reincarnate––has actually been a result of our attitudes as they have formed over the centuries. So what we try to do is spiritualize our consciousness, and we do it by working with the creative imagination.”

Harold Klemp, How to Find God, p. 51

Join us for an uplifting worship service which will provide us with the opportunity to recognize our inner spiritual resources, and how these resources help us in our daily lives. There will be a brief talk, a creative arts, a short spiritual contemplation and a discussion about the quotation from Harold Klemp, the spiritual leader of Eckankar.

Members of all faiths are invited to participate in the ECK Worship Service. Join other like-minded people seeking to bring more spiritual insight into their daily lives.

For more information, please go to our website:

www.eckinmass.org

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿
results.name: Sunday Service

results.description:
BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

Beginner Tango course is meant for people who either never ever danced Argentine Tango, took few classes long time ago or took few lessons quite recently but are not sure what they know or if they are ready for next level.

You will learn basics necessary to progress further. The material is presented in very organized manner allowing smooth progress from class to class. 

Please note that even if you dance other dances like salsa, swing, zouk or any of Ballroom or American Style dances, even if for years you took ballet, jazz, hip hop or any other of solo dances, you need to take the Beginner level class. The axis, the basis for the dance, musicality and partnership is completely different. Taking those 4 classes might be the life changing experience for you. It is obvious that having dance background helps, but it shall also give you enough experience to know that the basic classes are THE MOST IMPORTANT ONES, as they create a base for all your learning experience. What you don’t know will always and always chase you.

 It’s good to take this course to put all your information in order. You gain the necessary vocabulary and learn all the basic movements to be able to easily follow the explanations in higher level courses. Please respect our commitment to excellence. And make it your own.

No partner necessary. Join at any time – though we do recommend starting at the beginning of the cycle (see: http://www.ultimatetango.com/boston-classes.html for dates). You can take this course as many times as you find necessary for you.

The full course consists of 8 90-minutes classes plus exam/graduation even (about 4 hrs).


SIGN UP NOW: https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=208847&stype=-7&sTG=25&sView=week
results.how_to_find_us: Follow your intuition and detective instincts. Still cannot find it? Email us at: ultimatetango@gmail.com
results.name: Dive into Argentine Tango: BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

Our intentions:

• We create with each other a welcoming white racial justice culture

• We are present with each other, deepening relationships and community

• We support each other, to grow and be accountable in our work for racial justice

results.description:
Insecurity is underrated. In a society that values confidence and assertiveness, "insecure" is one of the worst, most damning insults with which to characterize a person. But what if we are missing out on the great beauty, insight, and connection that can come from embracing some of our insecurities? 

If you live in America today, you may have noticed a lot of talk about the virtue of security. Immigration debates rage over border security; threats of terrorism are addressed by the Department of Homeland Security; and the private home security industry is growing daily, with increasingly advanced alarm systems soon to be a $50 billion industry worldwide. It can be a fun game to notice how often politicians like Donald Trump and Ted Cruz speak, with great confidence, about the need for more security-- just don't make it a drinking game, or you may need your stomach pumped. 

Surely all of us want to be as safe as we can reasonably be. But as Alan Watts argued in his 1951 book The Wisdom of Insecurity, we all suffer and we are all mortal, so even trying to be 100% safe and secure is, by definition, an act of lying to ourselves. And, as Greg will argue in this talk, in a 2016 where change is the only constant, and where traditional sources of security for some, such as patriarchy and racism, are thankfully in decline: we have so much to gain if we can learn to accept and even value some of our own insecurity. 

Greg, who has been the Humanist Chaplain at Harvard University for over a decade, holds various advanced degrees, and is the New York Times bestselling author of Good Without God, will be speaking on a subject around which he has considerable expertise. After all, Greg has many years of experience at being insecure about his own insecurities! Only in recent years has he begun to accept his own lack of confidence as potentially a good thing, which in turn has allowed him to connect more deeply with his community, which has in turn caused him to notice that most of the people he loves and admires best are, non-coincidentally, insecure in some way. 

Join Greg for his first 2016 monthly talk at the Hub: with music, food, discussion circles, and more.

Prospective first-time attendees are especially encouraged to attend this event!

Childcare is available at this and all Hub Sunday programs. Please email [masked] to reserve a spot.
results.name: Greg Epstein: In Praise of Insecurity

group.name: The Humanist Hub in Harvard Square

This Game Viewing is for north of Boston drinking buddies and will be hosted by the Red Sox Natives and Wakefield Weeknights.

Please join us at Harrington's Irish Pub in Wakefield for a Patriots Game Viewing on Sunday, January 24, 2016  at 2:00pm  

This is the AFC Championship Game. Patriots play the Denver Broncos in Denver. The winner of the AFC Championship Game goes to the Super Bowl.

We choose Harrington's in order to avoid long lines and huge crowds expected at other large Sports Bars.

Harrington's Owners Lisa and Dan have reserved a section and tables for us. You can either sit in our section, watch the game at the bar, ask the hostess for a separate table reservation for a small group or just move around Harrington's.

This Game Viewing is designed for both serious football fans and others who may just want to casually hang out, have dinner and drinks or just socialize. Please let the serious fans sit near the Television Screens.

Arrive early to get a prime seat and for some pre-game socializing.

Game time is 3:05pm.

Ask the hostess for our reserved section.

Stay for the whole game or part of the game.

results.description:
Please join us at Harrington's Irish Pub in Wakefield for a Patriots Game Viewing on Sunday, January 24, 2016 at 2:00pm. 

This is the AFC Championship Game. Patriots play the Denver Broncos in Denver. The winner of the AFC Championship game goes to the Super Bowl!

We choose Harrington's in order to avoid the long lines and huge crowds expected at other large Sports Bars and because we have previously worked with Harrington's in the past.

Harrington's Owners Lisa and Dan have reserved a section and tables for us. You can either sit in our section, watch the game at the bar, ask the hostess for a separate table reservation for a small group or just move around inside Harrington's.

This Game Viewing is designed for both serious football fans and others who may just want to casually hang out, have dinner and drinks or just socialize. Please let the serious fans sit near the Television Screens!

Arrive early to get a prime seat and for some pre game socializing.

The earlier you arrive the better seat you get.

We will be there at 2:00pm one hour before game time.

Game Time is 3:05pm.

Ask the hostess for our reserved section.

Stay for the whole game or part of the game.

Stay for the NFC Championship Game that will follow at 6:40pm also.

Full menu available for purchase.

If this will be your first time meeting the Red Sox Natives crew and Wakefield Weeknights along with other invited groups please check out the photos of those who RSVP YES so you can find the group.

There is no cover.

Parking is free .


Harrington's Food and Spirits in downtown Wakefield is a cozy Irish Restaurant and Pub with two floors. We have been there before. The food is great and the full menu will be available for purchase.

There is free parking in downtown Wakefield in the public lot across from Harrington's in front of Bank of America and along Water and Main Streets. The location is T accessible by the 136 and 137 Bus from the Orange Line in Malden Center. And Commuter Rail accessible from North Station via the Reading and Haverhill Trains stopping at Wakefield Station with a less than 10 minute walk up Albion Street, right on to Main Street and 1 block to Water Street. If you are joining us from the City this is the way to go.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. Harrington's staff may take credit cards and there will be no group bill if you speak to your server first. If you are seated at a group table you may be part of a group bill. Everyone is responsible for their own food and drinks.

We hope to see you there.

Go Pats!

results.description:
Cold wind outside, forced hot air inside – winter in New England can dry you out both coming and going. Dry lips, chapped hands, and cracked skin are uncomfortable and persistent. Commercial moisturizers often contain alcohol and can irritate the very skin they’re supposed to heal. Fortunately, it’s simple enough to make your own herbal skin lotion – once you learn how you’ll never go back!

Learn a skin cream recipe to protect and nourish cold-chapped skin. Lotion recipes are based on the chemistry of creating an emulsion, a blend of oil and water soluble ingredients that requires the right ratios and some patience to achieve properly.

This is a hands-on class, no experience required! We’ll discuss how best to select herbs for lotion making, and we’ll perform a demonstration of the emulsifying process along with some tips for troubleshooting runny products.

Sunday, January 24th, 2016
2:00pm – 4:00pm
549 Columbus Ave, Boston MA
results.name: Herbal Lotions for Dry Winter Skin

The Foodicine Health Cooking Series For "Special Diets"

YES, YOU CAN EAT GOURMET ON THE LOW-FODMAP DIET FOR IRRITABLE BOWEL SYNDROME, CROHN'S DISEASE, AND COLITIS


Chef-Tim Maslow, Ribelle, Brookline, MA 2015 Food and Wine's "Best New Chef"
Dietitian-New York Times Best Selling Author Kate Scarlata, Boston, MA

Boston Public Market Kitchen, 100 Hanover Street Boston, MA

To Purchase Tickets To This Event Visit http://www.eventbrite.com/o/foodicine-health-inc-8383710024

Have you been diagnosed with Irritable Bowel Syndrome, Crohn's Disease or Colitis and think that your diet is now destined to be limited or boring?

Are you unsure of what you can or cannot eat on your new diet and are looking for ways to eat fabulous, yummy food?

Do you just want to learn new cooking techniques or new recipes that include ingredients that your physician or dietitian has told you are included on your prescribed diet?
Then the Foodicine Health “Yes, You Can Eat!” Cooking Series is for you! Join expert Dietitians and Celebrity Chefs as they discuss ways to:

Change your lifestyle and diet to help you to improve your health;
Cook delicious meals that fit into your dietary requirements, are fun and easy to prepare, and will delight your friends and family.
Each class will focus on a different “Special Diet” that is associated with a different chronic illness or food allergy. You can taste the recipes that the Chefs are cooking and will leave these classes with dietary information regarding your specific medical condition or allergy and with recipes that you will love to prepare at home! You will also learn that your future is destined to be gourmet, fun and delicious!

results.description:
Join us in reading and discussion around Colonize This!: Young Women of Color on Today's Feminism, edited by Daisy Hernandez and others


See the lower part of this description for a special plan to share in the discussion of this book.


From the Seal Press website:


It has been decades since women of color first turned feminism upside down, exposing the ‘70s feminist movement as exclusive, white, and unaware of the concerns and issues of women of color from around the globe. Now a new generation of brilliant, outspoken women of color is speaking to the concerns of a new feminism, and to their place in it.

Daisy Hernández of Ms. magazine and poet Bushra Rehman have collected a diverse, lively group of emerging writers who speak to their experience—to the strength and rigidity of community and religion, to borders and divisions, both internal and external—and address issues that take feminism into the twenty-first century. One writer describes herself as a “mixed brown girl, Sri-Lankan and New England mill-town white trash,” and clearly delineates the organizing differences between whites and women of color: “We do not kick ass the way the white girls do, in meetings of NOW or riot grrl. For us, it’s all about family.” A Korean American woman struggles to create her own identity in a traditional community: “Yam-ja-neh means nice, sweet, compliant. I’ve heard it used many times by my parents’ friends who don’t know shit about me.” An Arab American feminist deconstructs the “quaint vision” of Middle Eastern women with which most Americans feel comfortable.

This impressive array of first-person accounts adds a much-needed fresh dimension to the ongoing dialogue between race and gender.

.......................

Colonize This!: Young Women of Color on Today's Feminism is longer than some other books, and some people may not have time to read the whole thing.  Because of that, and also to add to our discussion dynamics, we'd like each person choose one particular piece of writing that you'll share, responding to these:

1) Summarize the writing in two minutes or less.
2) What could you identify with in the writing, or what was already familiar to you?
3) What was new to you, or what do you want to consider further from your part?
4) Any other comments on this part?
5) Share a quote from the writing you chose.

You can post the title of your part in the comments section below.  It's fine if you choose the same writing as another person.  If we find one that interests a lot of people, we may decide to have everyone read that one, and discuss it as a group.  (We'd still like everyone to choose a separate piece to present.)

If you want to read the whole book, that's great!  We'd just like you to be prepared to talk about one piece.


Because of space limitations, a maximum of 16 people can attend. Please be mindful when you RSVP that a waitlist is likely and update your RSVP if you're unable to attend or commit to reading the book.  

See you then!
results.name: Knapsack Book Discussion: Colonize This!: Young Women of Color on...

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 1/24 4:00

Robert De Niro, a grandfather widower, and Zac Efron, a fine young man in every respect is about to marry. Their quiet trip will take a strange turn when they find themselves caught up in the madness of "Spring Break" in Florida. Yep, right before Zacs wedding, (whose is an uptight guy), is tricked into driving his grandfather, (a perverted former Army General), to Florida for 'spring break'!

Gives us a glimpse of the excesses of all kinds that the pair will engage far from their daily routine. Sex, drugs and alcohol are scheduled for them!

Dirty Grandpa promises to be a sophomoric 'COMEDY' and a tad trashy!

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
This is an advanced full moon photo shoot, please sign up only if you have the necessary equipment and experience. Starting 15 minutes before the moon comes up (5:50), I will not be able to assist until after the rise.


This meetup needs near-clear skies and may be cancelled if it's too cloudy.

You will need: a sturdy tripod, a camera, a remote control/intervalometer, a long zoom lens of at least 150 mm focal length (better 200, up to 400), a 10 stop or higher neutral density filter for that lens. A second set of equipment (camera, tripod, long lens) makes is more worthwhile. Consider renting a lens if you don't have one.


The ICE 10-stop ND filter can be had very cheaply, it's a great filter with very minor color cast. Buy one for your largest lens and step-down rings for smaller lenses: 82mm, 77 mm. The Formatt-Hitech 16 stop ND filter can also be had at Amazon now, but it is expensive: 82mm and 77 mm. Get some step-down rings.


1) We will attempt to shoot a continuous moon streak, which is not clipped, that means: no highlights blown out, the moon will have full color resolution.


Here is how to do this:


• I selected the location to allow for a composition as above. There will be an interesting foreground for the moon to go over or behind (the Boston Logan tower).

• Compose such that about the bottom third is landscape and the top 2/3 are sky. Compose such that the moon comes up in the lower left corner (not too close to the edge) and you may have to make quick last minute adjustments once you see the moon coming over the horizon. Don't fret missing the first seconds, as the moon fills the space as it comes up.


• Plan for a very long, single exposure, around 20-40 minutes (after that it exits the frame), exposure time will be calculated for ambient landscape (with a high ISO preview - HIP - before the moon comes up).


• The shot is taken with a long zoom (150mm or more, ideally[masked]mm), which is what makes the moon look "large" compared to the area you zoom into (the town and jetty above, the foreground object in our event).


• The lens is equipped with an extreme neutral density (ND) filter, 10 stops or more. 8 stops might work for the second approach, less will not. This is done to get the moon correctly exposed and avoid clipping its lights during the long exposure necessary for the landscape through the filter. The moon stays in "one place" only for about 4 minutes, so the exposure needs to be right for those 4 minutes. After that, the moon is right "next" to its prior self in terms of composition, the light no longer adds to the previous position. An ND filter denser than 10 stops would only make the moon streak darker, the ambient landscape would still be exposed right as determined with the HIP.


• A high ISO preview (HIP) will give you an approximate starting point for the landscape exposure. Consider that it will get a little darker as the moon comes up. This is one day after full moon, chosen on purpose, because the sun sets an hour before the moon rises.


• The exposure time and aperture are then chosen for the length of the moon trail as well as the surrounding landscape.


• You can adjust exposure by raising the ISO or changing the aperture. The landscape will be far away, so it won't make much difference if you use f/5.6 or f/11, which gives you an easy adjustment for exposure.

• The above is shot at f/5.6 and ISO 400 for 47 minutes (to get the ambient exposure right) and a 16-stop ND filter. However, the moon exited the frame around 30 minutes, I included too much foreground. I calculated the exposure and was spot-on, but the 16-stop was a bit too much, hence, ISO 400. A 10-stop ND filter would have allowed me to shoot at ISO 50 and f/16, same exposure time.


• The foreground was actually blurred (the jetty moved up and down), so I took a short (1-minute) exposure afterwards and combined the sky and foreground in Photoshop.

• If you have enough patience, a dark frame of the same length, ISO and with closed aperture and cap on the lens is recommended afterwards, because 20-40 minute exposures have a lot of fixed pixel noise. Subtract the dark frame from the image using PixelFixer. You can enable Long Exposure Noise Reduction (LENR), but you won't see the image and can't take a short exposure until another 30-40 minutes after the exposure.

For this first time in a group, I chose an easy to get to location: the harborwalk and our zoom-into object is the airport tower. Picture this with a moon streak going behind (and perhaps a few airplane trails going up and down (artist's (ahem) rendition of the moon streak behind the tower):

Future locations will be more exciting, but it's hard to find a stand-alone feature that is interesting enough, between 1 and 1.5 unobstructed miles away and in the right direction of the rising moon. I used PlanIt! Pro to plan this out, better than TPE. Suggestions welcome!

2) Assembled moon streak


• The below image was taken with a second camera (and tripod) with a 10-stop filter, which was not quite dense enough, I had to shoot at ISO 50 (not 100) and f/32 to reduce the amount of light. Exposure time was limited to a few minutes initially, then I had to gradually reduce the exposure time and take multiple shots, 30-seconds at the end. I then stacked all images together for the resulting photo. Overall length is roughly 25 minutes. Easier to do, because you don't need to plan ahead for 30 minutes. The nice thing about this one is that the moon does not exit the frame. The streak is not as smooth and you can see the breaks between exposures as small indents, even though interruption between any two shots was only a few seconds. The moon moves quickly with a long zoom!


3) Full moon rising

If you have a 2nd or 3rd camera, you can also simply shoot the full moon coming up over the horizon, which is substantially easier to do and does not require ND filters. Exposure time is somewhere shorter than 1/90th of a second, ideally shot with mirror up and using a remote control. The challenge here is to not blow the moon out (it has features that you want to show) but also not blur it and to get a composition with an interesting foreground, perhaps with the moon half behind it. Because it is one day after full moon, the landscape will be rather dark when the moon rises (an hour after sunset) and you will have to boost shadows in post-processing a lot.


It will be cold and you will be standing around not doing much. Dress accordingly, bring gloves and head gear. This will be a rather short meetup, about an hour to 90 minutes. Once the moon is way up, it becomes uninteresting and too bright, but you can certainly stay to shoot things around the harborwalk (like the aquarium right behind us) only or zoom in on the moon alone.


The meetup address is a dead-end and no parking right there. Use Google maps to find a nearby garage, but don't use the very expensive Aquarium garage.

Following the meditation, we will have a  party with  food,and excellent opportunities to connect with other attendees. Meditators, Yogis and Yoginis, Buddhists, Reiki practitioners, healers, massage therapists, newcomers to the spiritual path  and other holistic practitioners- this is a great place to network. We had a  very uplifting meditation event recently on December 13th, 2015 and want to continue the good vibrations into 2016. Bring a friend and enjoy!

results.description:
I am interested in the subject of 'solitude'.

Many of us who are considered 'extroverted', but we really know ourselves to be more of a true 'introvert' . We are often  very social, but who get exhausted after extended interactions even with friends, let alone work....solitude is essential to our well-being. (Thanks to Jim, B who posted about this on Facebook recently..it really made me think about this subject.)

That being said, some of us who are 'introverts' are yet often vigorously connecting on social media...for hours a day. I admit it; I'm one of them. Why? Because I don't have to actually 'talk' and there's no 'sound' (being extremely noise sensitive, this matters to me.) I can engage or disengage whenever I want...I rarely feel  lonely because there's ALWAYS someone to 'talk' to /connect with.

I never feel alone..maybe bored or frustrated; but not 'alone', even though I haven't exactly met the love of my life (yet) so am still single.....(Some people believe that being single is inherently lonely; I don't).

As I get older & older, I CRAVE more alone time, unlike in my 20's/30's/& early 40's and simply HAD to have people around. I remember those days, but now the beauty & essence of quiet time....well, it's restorative.....essential to my own well-being. It comes from a greater sense of self-esteem & self-awareness, not fear. I scored VERY high on the "Quirky Alone" quiz that we discussed a few years ago! :)

Anyway, let's discuss is over drinks & pub food....hopefully, the snow will all be off our cars & we can move about & go places and NOT hibernate (or be alone) for at least a few hours! LOL  :)
results.name: Last Minute Post-Snow Dinner: Talk About Solitude, Identity & Well Being

results.description: Step out into the night for a short moonlit walk and then enjoy a celebration of the trees. Bring a reading, poem, song, picture, or prayer related to trees, your favorite fruit or nuts, and enjoy a celebration of the trees. Foods made with wheat and barley, grapes or grape juice, figs, dates, pomegrantes, and olives or foods will olive oil are special for the holiday, but any kind of fruit or nut is welcome. The seder will be held indoors at Peace Lutheran Church, which is right next to the trailhead for the Upper Mill Brook Conservation Area. This event is co-sponsored by Ma'yan Tikvah - A Wellspring of Hope and will be led by Rabbi Katy Allen.
results.how_to_find_us: The trailhead is by Peace Lutheran Church, next to Cong. Or Atid on Rt. 126 north of Wayland Center.

results.description:
</a>

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

<a href="http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com">http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com


(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 25-35 - SOLD OUT FOR MEN

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 25-35 - SOLD OUT FOR MEN

group.name: Events for Single Professionals of Boston

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

results.description: There will be a stimulus for each meeting to inspire the conversation. The stimulus can be anything, such as a picture, a short story, a breaking news, etc. Each meeting includes stimulus introduction, small group and whole group discussion, and personal reflection. Every attendee is encouraged (actually required) to raise questions inspired by the stimulus. And then we will discuss why these questions are important; how these questions relate to one's personal life experience; what is one's perspectives on these questions, and how the discussion might affect one's future thinking. This is a place to share our souls and learn from others. This is not a place to promote any particular school of thoughts, beliefs, faiths, political views, etc. We must keep an open mind, respect each other, and agree to disagree.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Joey Tuccio, President of Stage 32's Happy Writers, will be providing helpful tips on how to make their scripts better, then giving them time to rehearse before their scheduled pitch time. results.description:
Excited to announce our speakers for the event:

Building a National-Scale Cancer Genomics Cloud

Gaurav Kaushik, PhD, will discuss the motivation, inception, and deployment of the Cancer Genomics Cloud (CGC), built by SevenBridges and funded by the National Cancer Institute. CGC hosts The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), one of the world's largest cancer genomics data collections, and provides computational resources and optimized, portable bioinformatics tools to analyze it— at any scale, immediately, collaboratively, and reproducibly. Using Docker and the Common Workflow Language, it is also possible to port any tool of your liking to the CGC -- where you have access to free computational credits and more than a petabyte of genomic data to analyze. 

Career Networking Panel

We will be doing a Q&A with a diverse group of leaders in the Boston bioinformatics community to gain an understanding of what they are looking for when hiring bioinformaticians. 

Including:

John Keilty of Third Rock Ventures

Andrew Gruen, PhD of SevenBridges

Katrina Steiling, MD  Boston University School of Medicine


Chris Roberts, PhD of Biogen 

Matthew Eaton, PhD of Syros Pharmaceuticals

Moderated by: Danielle Greenawalt, PhD of AstraZeneca

Thank you to our sponsor Seven Bridges for helping to make this event possible https://www.sbgenomics.com/

Seven Bridges is the cloud-powered platform for population-scale bioinformatics. The world’s largest research institutions — including the governments of the U.S. and UK — use Seven Bridges’ software to help them analyze, store, and act on genomic and other biological data.

results.description:
Release Date:

November 30, -0001


Rating:

R


Synopsis:

Michael Moore understands the art of provocation. From Roger & Me to Bowling for Columbine to Fahrenheit 9/​​11, he's been ahead of the cultural curve with films that galvanized audiences and escalated box-office records. Now, six years since his last film and with another US election around the corner, he delivers a fresh surprise that feels current yet perfectly timeless. Filming abroad without drawing attention from American media, Moore reunites his A-team, including producers Carl Deal and Tia Lessin (directors of the Oscar-nominated Trouble the Water), and brings us a funny and provocative work that's guaranteed to stir up conversation. The United States' long history of invading countries and pushing agendas has produced results that are, to say the least, mixed. What if the US could do a better job at invading? That's the premise for this film, which sends Moore on an epic journey.

https://youtu.be/r4JJvfrkH3M
results.name: Where To Invade Next   1-25  Mon.      AMC  7 PM

results.description:
It’s that time of year again – the year-end statements are appearing in your mailbox, and the storefront tax-prep offices you never notice during most of the year seem to be blossoming like weird winter flowers.

Will this year’s tax-prep season be less awful and stressful than last year’s? And more important, are there steps you can take during this year’s season to save tax expense and put yourself and your practice onto a sounder footing for 2016 and beyond?

Ron Loberfeld will have answers for you. He and his firm provide accounting, audit, and tax services to individuals and small businesses in the Boston area and throughout New England.

Like all SPC meetings, this one will be interactive, and Ron will be glad to respond to your questions. But here are some topics likely to come up:

• Should you consider incorporation or some other form of business organization?

• As a consultant, how should you think about retirement planning – and what does that mean during tax season?

• What about deductions for office in the home?

• What about rental income and expense?

• What can you do to minimize your risk of an audit?

• What can you do if you are audited?

• What should you be doing to protect yourself and your consulting practice from identity theft?

The cost is $45 for members and first time attendees. All others are $55. Late registration for members is $55 and $65 for all others. Please remember to go here to register http://spconsultants.org/event-2113581 or bring a check or cash to the event.

results.description:
This is a 4 week class and runs from Jan. 25th to Feb. 15th. From 6:30 - 8:30 PM.  "Learning the Tarot" is great fun for both the beginner and those looking to go back to the basics and review. Do you know that where you are in your life is a direct result of all the decisions you have made in the past?  If you are not happy with where you are in your life, learning to make better decisions will help! The cards are a divination tool, providing guidance you can use to advise your family and friends as well as gain insights for yourself. We will be going through each card individually, as well as leaning several layouts including, the Celtic Cross. We will learn a spread and being doing basic readings the first night.

Bring your Tarot cards and a 3-ring binder/notebook to hold/store handouts. For those students who do not have Tarot cards, "The Rider Deck" or Rider-Waite tarot deck is recommended.

To register for this class you must go onto the Billerica Rec. Site: http://recreation.town.billerica.ma.us/wbwsc/webtrac.wsc/wbsplash.html?wbp=1 

There you can choose your payment method.

Is there someone you know who you think would be interested or benefit from this event - let them know!

We look forward to seeing you!

Love & Light,

Joanie

Debbie

*** Would you like to purchase a TIBS gift certificate? ***

VISA/MC/DISCOVER are accepted for all gift certificates

TIBS gift certificates are available in any amount.

results.description:
Please join us at 6:30 pm on Monday, January 25th at District Hall, 75 Northern Avenue in South Boston, to discuss the launch of an exciting not for profit project called The Building Brighter Foundation.

Building Brighter's mission will be to construct sustainable tiny homes for the homeless and low income families while working with local governments to alter and improve zoning laws that will benefit the entire tiny house movement across Massachusetts and throughout New England. They are currently in discussions with municipalities in the Boston area and in the western part of the state regarding a pilot project.

In addition to looking for ideas and feedback from the tiny house community, they are seeking founding board members, volunteers, grant writers, fundraisers and a number of other support positions. Interested in getting involved? Come be a part of the conversation!
results.name: Help Support a Local Non-Profit Seeking to Build Tiny Houses for the Homeless

results.description:
Discover the holistic benefits of the Feldenkrais Method®!

Each 90 minute Awareness Through Movement class consists of guided attention through carefully sequenced movements that are designed to stimulate your curiosity, challenge your coordination, and bring you into a new way of being in both body and mind.


By encouraging us to slow down, reduce effort, and delve into the building blocks of our movement, Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement enables us to discover previously unnoticed areas of habitual tension and unlock new possibilities for moving freely.  Come and experience for yourself what an effective resource it can be for stress relief, improving balance and posture, and alleviating chronic pain at the source. 

Classes are open to adults at all fitness levels. No prior experience necessary.  

Drop-ins are welcome, but RSVPing will give you the opportunity to influence the content of the class for your needs and interests!
results.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement® class!
