results.description:
Agenda 

• 6:30: Networking & Pizza

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Tips for Properly Scaling Your Dev Team

Domagoj Gojak

Latest CMS usage statistics show that WordPress is growing again. Having that in mind it’s clear that the dev teams will grow as well and in this talk you will see how to tackle issues like platform difference, code quality insurance, multi environment/feature feature development with certain methodologies and tools.

Bio

23 year old web and software developer from Split, Croatia. Working as a Lead Developer at Slicejack, company that produces highly reliable custom WordPress solutions for both domestic and international clients. Wrote his first lines of code when he was just 12 years old and hasn’t stopped since. Now has more than 5 years of experience with PHP and has been using WordPress on a daily basis for almost 2 years now. Automation, security and pizza lover.

Presentation 2: What's CDN, and how to use it with WordPress

Dan Zuzevich

We will talk basics about CDNs, how/why it's important, and then walk through a setup of Cloudflare and configure with w3 total cache.

Bio

Dan Zuzevich is the founder and head SEO analyst at the new Boston based company Dizzy Cat. Educated in Computer Networking & Security from the UMass Boston College of Management, his passion for technology and entrepreneurship has lead him to focus his efforts on the Web Technology & SEO industry. He believes that we are currently in a very interesting time technology wise, and that with proper SEO & Marketing techniques, small business owners can rocket themselves to success. You can visit his company at http://www.dizzycat.net

results.description:
Impromptu Philosophizers are spontaneous, existentially driven meetings and discussions. I am pleased to reintroduce this popular event! They are casual meetings at cafes or pubs that may or may not have a specific topic, and may even be scheduled “on the spur of the moment!" 


****************************************

ADMISSION FEE: Bronze and Gold Members are admitted free.  Basic members  are required to pay a $5.50 admission fee:  PLEASE PAY HERE. Any unpaid registration (RSVP) will be changed to "not attending." DO NOT RSVP IF YOU HAVE NOT FIRST PURCHASED OR ACQUIRED THE REQUISITE MEMBERSHIP OR ADMISSION!

Gold and Bronze Memberships entitle you to attend great events such as Impromptu Philosophizers, study group meetings and more! Instead of paying the admission fee, you can purchase a paid membership (for as little as $15 per year) on the Membership Page.

***************************************** 

It's great to know that there is now a way for people to meet but with no particular agenda other than that of satisfying the need to talk and philosophize about what's on their minds. Whether the interest or concern involves current events or politics, cultural or intellectual issues, personal stuff, pure philosophy or whatever else is on your mind we can all benefit from sharing philosophical perspectives.


"Therapy for the sane," a term used by Gerd Achenbach (founder of the modern philosophical counseling movement), may partially suggest the Impromptu Philosophizer concept but it is more multifaceted than, say, an occasional "therapy" session after a trying day. IPs are designed to be fun, engaging and unique opportunities for creating a near spontaneous venue to meet other group members for the purpose of sharing thoughts, ideas and concerns from a philosophical perspective.

TO REACH ME AT MY OFFICE, CALL[masked]
results.name: Impromptu Philosophizer

results.description:
Our Book choice for January is A Window Opens, by Elizabeth Egan

Fans of I Don’t Know How She Does It and Where’d You Go, Bernadette will cheer at this “fresh, funny take on the age-old struggle to have it all” (People) about what happens when a wife and mother of three leaps at the chance to fulfill her professional destiny—only to learn every opportunity comes at a price.

In A Window Opens, beloved books editor at Glamour magazine Elisabeth Egan brings us Alice Pearse, a compulsively honest, longing-to-have-it-all, sandwich generation heroine for our social-media-obsessed, lean in (or opt out) age. Like her fictional forebears Kate Reddy and Bridget Jones, Alice plays many roles (which she never refers to as “wearing many hats” and wishes you wouldn’t, either). She is a mostly-happily married mother of three, an attentive daughter, an ambivalent dog-owner, a part-time editor, a loyal neighbor and a Zen commuter. She is not: a cook, a craftswoman, a decorator, an active PTA member, a natural caretaker or the breadwinner. But when her husband makes a radical career change, Alice is ready to lean in—and she knows exactly how lucky she is to land a job at Scroll, a hip young start-up which promises to be the future of reading, with its chain of chic literary lounges and dedication to beloved classics. The Holy Grail of working mothers―an intellectually satisfying job and a happy personal life―seems suddenly within reach.

Despite the disapproval of her best friend, who owns the local bookstore, Alice is proud of her new “balancing act” (which is more like a three-ring circus) until her dad gets sick, her marriage flounders, her babysitter gets fed up, her kids start to grow up and her work takes an unexpected turn. Readers will cheer as Alice realizes the question is not whether it’s possible to have it all, but what does she―Alice Pearse―really want?
results.name: North Shore Book Club

Participate in a study on English question formation in Hindi English bilinguals taking place at Northeastern University!

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait 5-10 minutes for people to show, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.

(NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Digital Luminescence:
"Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic" - Arthur C Clark

In this biweekly meetup, we will explore a wide variety of multimedia and technology based art. Come out to learn and play with programmable lighting, cameras, projectors, generative visual applications and interactive hardware. I am excited to collaboratively explore topics and learn with others.
Bring projects you are working for feedback and help from members at the end of class.
-----------------This Week--------------------
Cost: $5 donation to the makerspace.

Session 1: TV, video, Feedback.
We will be exploring different traditional analog methods for generating visuals.
This Session will have two tracks, depending on material availability and interest.

track 1:
First we will explore some Video Techniques and usage of video feedback.
We will play with what kind of video mixing we can accomplish with stock components. (without hacking too much)
and if someone has a video mixer, we can do some really cool stuff.

track 2:
In the second part of this course, we will be exploring hacking the electronics of a display to generate interesting visuals.

Ideally, I would like to accomplish something like this:
http://crackedraytube.com/pdfs/crackingraytubes.pdf

Bring (if you can/have them post in comments so we are not bringing 6 of everything):
o Laptop
o different sizes of digital cameras.
o Video Camera with output. (HDMI, AV out, etc.)
o disposable small CRT TVs/monitor
o AV signal combiner
o AV mixer board.
o Tools.

Inspiration:
o Nahm June Paik:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VEAUjFLSqXY

-----------------More Info--------------------

There will be a general topic that each session is based around. While it is not as firm as a curriculum, and I am NOT an expert on the areas covered. They are just interesting areas that I have been meaning to experiment around with and might interest people. I will be doing a short introduction on the subject and a certain amount of time will probably be spent experimenting in the topic of choice each session. The Idea is to narrow the field a bit for each session, and attack a different thing each time to demonstrate and cover a bunch of varying topics within the pretty wide scope of this meetup.

the general structure:
8:00 PM - Class starts
8:30PM-8:40PM - Primer on the night's subject. NOT supposed to be ridiculously in depth, just an intro or inspiration.

8:40-9:00: discussion questions and brainstorming. For those that know additional information on the subject, this is the part when it is brought up. This is also the part of the night where we come up with initial project ideas surrounding the presented subject. 9:00-10:00: collaborative experimentation. This is the part that we play around with what we can get done together or in groups. The focus of this hour is less on product, and more on collaboration and mutual assistance to get people up and running with new techniques. Those who are already comfortable should help those who are less comfortable. 10:00-10:15: wrap up. Re-gather and Discuss next session's topic. 10:15-??: Personal Project Time - As available, Get feedback and help on personal projects you are working on from the members of the group.

-------------------About me--------------------------
I am an artist and engineer. I went to school for animation and am now creating and installing LED sculptures and generative installations at large parties and concerts around New England. I enjoy experimenting and intermixing new technology and art.

-----------------Schedule/Upcoming-----------------------
Session 1: TV, video, Feedback.
Bring:
Laptop
different sizes of digital cameras.

disposable TV monitor.

results.description:
I believe in the photographer's magic — the ability to stir the soul with light and shape and colour. A. Nasser


Heat wave on Tuesday! Temp will be 45 so let's take full advantage and do a full day of photography. We will shoot inside and out moving around the city for a variety of shooting situation and locations using the Boston Public Library as our base of operations. So get ready for a fun, intensive day of building your creative seeing skills. Wear comfortable shoes and warm clothes. We will be on the move. We will take a short lunch break so bring a brown bag, or buy what you like at the sandwich shop. 

If you want to create photographs rather than take snapshots, you already know this has little to do with the camera you choose everything to do with how you see. Do you notice what others miss? Do you stop to photograph things that others walk right by? Do the smallest details of a scene take your breath away? 

Then you are already on the path to seeing creatively. Join us to take the next steps. This workshop is for you if:

•  You have explored the idea of design in photography but are not sure yet how to translate those ideas to your own work. We will cover topics like dynamic tension, visual balance, perspective, and form.

•  You are sometimes disappointed that your photos don’t quite match your experience of beauty. 

• You are not sure what to do to make your photos more powerful and compelling. They seem flat and lack depth.

• You are curious about moving off the Auto setting on your camera for more creative freedom. You would love to blur the background, or catch the action, but how? 

Photo by workshop participant: 

In this hands on workshop you will do a series of fun photo assignments to discover how the visual elements of color, light, texture, line and shape help you capture the magic of the moment. You will receive critique and coaching during the program so you can clearly see how to apply what you learn step by step. 

The strategies for seeing you explore in this workshop can be applied to any type of photography you enjoy including nature, landscape, people, macro, and abstract. Get ready to have fun, go slow, and experience a shift in how you photograph the beauty of your life. 

Creative Seeing rekindles our sense of wonder and joy. It renews our creative self  and invites us to create something of beauty through our photography.

BPL Lion photo by workshop participant beautiful use of natural lighting. Gives the shape depth and form. 

During this workshop the 5 secrets to creating photos we love to share will be revealed. You will discover:

•  How to capture creative design elements of color, light, texture and line to create stunning images 

•  How to use dynamic composition structures beyond the rule of thirds for added depth and dimension

• How to use aperture and shutter priority settings on your camera for more creative freedom 

• How to see with your heart and express the essence of the subject in a way that moves us

•  How to enter the "flow" state using mindful breathing techniques to connect to your subject

Before you can really connect with your subject, you need to shift into a more “in the moment” mindset. During this workshop you will be guided through some simple mindfulness exercises you can use anytime any where to help you slow down and be more present. 

These simple techniques will immediately open your eyes to more subtle qualities of color, light, texture and shape that usually go unnoticed. A wonderful side benefit is the fact that this method, called Flow-tography, also reduces stress and increases your sense of wellbeing.

You will also receive lesson cards summarizing the content of the class and assignments so you can practice again on your own after the workshop. You will meet some great like minded people who also enjoy photography. Don't don't worry about your skill level. Everyone can learn to see creatively.

Tuition for this  workshop is $85.00

We are  limiting this class to 10 participants so please RSVP now if you would like a space. 

Hope to see you there!

Suzanne

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

The QS World MBA Tour will be returning to Boston on Tuesday, January 26th at The Colonnade Hotel. We would like to invite you to attend our event for free (a saving of $15) but places are limited so make sure you register today.

As the competition for top jobs becomes fiercer, an MBA can be a critical success factor, providing you with a competitive edge. Understanding what top business schools want is vital to getting into the MBA program of your choice. Our event aims to provide you with the tools

Take advantage of this exclusive opportunity to speak face-to-face with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools. The QS World MBA Tour Boston will be making a stop at the Colonnade Hotel on January 26th from 4pm -9pm. 

Our event is your opportunity to meet with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools. 

As an attendee, you will be eligible to apply for exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M and attend panels and seminars to have all of your MBA questions answered in one place.

Our goal is to provide ambitious professionals like you with the best tools in order to facilitate your personal and professional development. We ensure that you have access to top business schools and education experts to help make this very important decision. 

Attending Business Schools Include:
Boston University, Boston College, UMass-Amherst, George Washington Univ., Northeastern Univ., Tufts Univ. - Fletcher, Univ. of Arizona - Eller, Vanderbilt Univ., Univ. of Miami, Suffolk Univ., Nova Southeastern Univ. London School of Economics and Political Science and more

During this event you can:
• Meet face-to-face with admissions directors from top international and local b-schools
• Apply for $1.7M of exclusive MBA scholarships to help finance your MBA
• Gain advice on the MBA essay, application and interview 

Entry is free for members of the meetup group, but places are limited so make sure you Register for FREE. Present a copy of this email to obtain free entrance to the Boston event. 

Registration Link: http://goo.gl/tbQedB

results.description:
EXCLUSIVE FREE ENTRY to the World's Top Business School Event

Please click on the following link to REGISTER FOR FREE as an RSVP on this group alone does not guarantee entry to the event: http://goo.gl/Ckvmz9

The QS World MBA Tour will be returning to Boston on January 26th at The Colonnade Hotel. We would like to invite you to attend our event for free (a saving of $15) but places are limited so make sure you register today.

As the competition for top jobs becomes fiercer, an MBA can be a critical success factor, providing you with a competitive edge. Understanding what top business schools want is vital to getting into the MBA program of your choice. Our event aims to provide you with the tools

Take advantage of this exclusive opportunity to speak face-to-face with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools. You will also be able to get advice on your MBA applications from experts. Event attendees are eligible to apply for a pool of exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M

Business schools attended in Spring 2015:

Boston College – Carroll, University of Boston, George Washington University, Johns Hopkins, Northeastern University Amore, Purdue University, University of Arizona, Hult.

During this event you can:

Ø  Meet face-to-face with admissions directors from top international and local business schools

Ø  Apply for $1.7M of exclusive MBA scholarships to help finance your MBA

Ø  Attend pre fair panel and presentations

Don't forget to register today to guarantee free entry: http://goo.gl/Ckvmz9

We look forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
Lunar New Year is undeniably the most important holiday to many persons of Asian descent around the globe, especially Chinese.  As a salute to Asian cultures, Get Konnected! is partnering with the National Association of Asian American Professional (NAAP) Boston to honor Michele Wu as Boston’s first Asian American City Council President and the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce's newly inducted President and CEO Jim Rooney.  Come join us as we salute Asian cultures and Greater Boston's key influencers at Boston's chicest venue, The Liquid Art House. Registration is $15.00.  Attendees will enjoy a cash bar and complimentary hors d’oeuvres will be served throughout the event.  For register, please visit the following link: http://conta.cc/1mCijvd. We are looking forwarding to your participation!

Get Konnected!

results.description:
Release Date:

February 26, 2016


Rating:

Not Yet Rated


Synopsis:

Inspired by true events, Eddie the Eagle is a feel-good story about Michael “Eddie” Edwards (Taron Egerton), an unlikely but courageous British ski-jumper who never stopped believing in himself – even as an entire nation was counting him out. With the help of a rebellious and charismatic coach (played by Hugh Jackman), Eddie takes on the establishment and wins the hearts of sports fans around the world by making an improbable and historic showing at the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics. From producers of Kingsman: The Secret Service, Eddie the Eagle stars Taron Egerton as Eddie, the loveable underdog with a never say die attitude.


https://youtu.be/hyzQjVUmIxk

results.description:
It's PARTY GAMES NIGHT

Bring your favorite game or just join in on the one's we have

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a night of Party Games. There have been a lot of new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start around 6:00pm or so, early birds (before 6pm) can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

See you there!!
results.name: PARTY GAME NIGHT

results.description:
Hello everyone!

Let's continue with our discussion on Burton Malkiel's "A random walk down Wall Street" with chapters 4-6. Please feel free to join even if you have not read the chapters or don't have the book yet. All levels of investment experience are welcome. We look forward to seeing you!

P.S. We are cutting the meeting short to go to the Boston Expat and World Traveler Meetup, which is occurring next door at Tavern in the Square at 7pm. It's basically like going to two meetups at once! (Should you choose to do so) 🙂
results.name: Investment meetup

results.description:
Hello everyone. We have three talks for us this month:

• "Using the Exception comment to help maintain mature, large-scale Sass projects" by Eric Bailey, a User Experience designer at Cantina

• "Optimizing Animations on the Web" by David Putney, UI/UX consultant and front-end developer at Cantinaand 

• "Zurb Foundation 6, what is updated and how to get started" by Daigo Fujiwara, Web Developer at HBR.org/Founder Baseball Hack Day


Gathering and networking (pizza and refreshments courtesy of Curate Partners, Thank you!) at 6, talk starts at 6:45. 


 Talk and presenter details


Using the Exception comment to help maintain mature, large-scale Sass projects


Description: Sass addresses the weaknesses of CSS. It brings CSS out of the lofty realm of the academic and turns it into something far friendlier to the daily workflow of front end developers or designers. However, despite these nice features, and sometimes because of them, teams can run into problems with their stylesheets as files grow along with the project. Careful use of Sass techniques, including the Exception comment, can help bring that under control. 


Bio: Eric Bailey is a User Experience designer and front end dabbler working at Cantina, a Digital Design & Development Agency located in the Fort Point Channel. He is a strong advocate of semantics and accessibility, and enjoys creating straightforward, device-agnostic solutions that address the practical, physical, cognitive, and emotional needs of the user.


Optimizing Animations on the Web

Bio: David Putney worked for 20 years in the newspapers business, where he’s been a reporter, copy editor, print designer and co-founder of a daily newspaper. Most recently he worked for The Boston Globe, where he designed BDCWire.com and Cruxnow.com, among other projects. He is currently is a UI/UX consultant and front-end developer at Cantina, a digital consulting agency in the Fort Point area of Boston. 

Zurb Foundation 6, what is updated and how to get started

Description: Zurb released a new version of Foundation for Sites, a CSS and Front-End Framework last month. Daigo will walk through the features and also show how you can get up and running with a new site using this framework in just few minutes. Great for getting something up really quick, like in a hackathon. We can discuss pros and cons of css and front end frameworks in general as well.


Bio: Daigo Fujiwara is a front end web developer at Harvard Business Review, and founder/organizer of Baseball Hack Day, Fun, friendly, free, one-day, on-site hacking/coding competition for baseball fans, happening in Boston March 19, 2016. Follow him at @DaigoFuji on twitter/github 


---

There will be drinks and pizza courtesy of Curate Partners Thank you!! Also Thank you Upstatement for providing us with meetup space.

CASCADE BOS is a community for tech-minded designers and design-savvy developers. We aim to be a community where members can learn from each other about ever-changing front-end technology and web design trends. CASCADE BOS is run by volunteers.
results.name: "CSS Comments", "Animation Optimization", and "Zurb Foundation 6"

results.description:
Everyday I'm amazed at how powerful google sheets has become. Not a day goes by that I don't show someone a quick tip that completely changes how they work. 

Come join me for an hour and I'll share my workflows and strategies for managing huge amounts of data. I'll share all my pro tips with you that I've learned through the last 3 years of doing things wrong, and I promise you'll learn something that you didn't know before.

I hold teacher certification in both Microsoft Excel and Apple Numbers, and I find myself abandoning this dated software for an internet spreadsheet that's capable of anything.

• We'll cover the basic concepts and the benefits of a sheet connected to the internet.


• Import a ton of contacts and some sample data that would come along with them.


• Organize and clean up a mess of a spreadsheet that someone else made.


• And demonstrate effective ways to use this stuff in ways that will immediately change how you work tomorrow.

I can't wait to share this with you and hope that you drop whatever your doing to kick off your 2016 work year off with some new ninja worthy skills!

Don't forget to RSVP

See you soon,

-Erik
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the rear entrance of the building.
results.name: Become a Google Sheet Ninja in 1 hour.

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until further notice, we're in Kresge 201 (which has been newly-refurbished), at the top of the open stairwell near the guard's desk near the Countway Courtyard entrance to the Kresge Building.

Yiran Zhang and Fred (ZHOU Hanlin) from PRC host these friendly meetups (in Kresge 201) while Justin Kwan is in Taiwan.  
Enter as you have long done; then walk UP the open stairway near the security guard's desk.

* Mandarin speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?
* English speakers want to learn Mandarin?
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Mandarin?

Our location this week is Kresge 201 (remodeled classroom) in the most gracious and globally conscious Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (HCSPH) where health-conscious and energy-conscious building and curriculum modifications have been made.

Until further notice, we're in Kresge 201, at the top of the open stairwell near the guard's desk near the Countway Courtyard entrance to the Kresge Building.

All attendees need to register IN ADVANCE to get an HSPH building permission for the night.

E-Mail [masked] to register your intent AND sign YES on this meetup.

下午6点到晚上8点3

PLEASE (try to) request by 4 pm the day before the Tuesday evening event.

* Harvard Square to LMA is about 30 minutes on #66 bus or M2 Harvard bus
* Green Line E-Line comes to Brigham Circle, then walk BACK to crosswalk, then to the building
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, via Tremont Street to Brigham Circle
* Walking from Brookline is about 10 minutes - via Huntington Avenue or Longwood Avenue
* MFA, NEU, Wentworth, and Colleges of the Fenway are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue
* Route 9 comes right into the area, via Brookline - passes Huntington Avenue D-line stop
* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find)

Show your CURRENT LOCAL ID to the HSPH Security Guard on duty, then walk up the open indoor stairwell near the Kresge security guard, then straight up the stairwell, then turn left to Kresge 201 (follow signs to Kresge 201).

E-Mail [masked]
for a building pass if you don't have a Harvard ID; we convene in Kresge 201;
you may wish to ask the HCSPH security guard how to access Kresge 201

PLEASE plan to show up early so we can begin our 'bilingual introductions' on time, so our presenter can begin (and end) on time.
results.how_to_find_us: Show your CURRENT LOCAL ID to the HSPH Security Guard, then go UP the OPEN stairwell (follow signs to Kresge 201, IN THE CORNER)

results.description:

results.description:
Happy New Year Gophers!

We're going to kick off the new year with two great full-length talks this January. 

Our talk(s):

1. Fighting the FUD by Mark Bates

A look at how you can sell Go to your boss, clients, and fellow co-workers. I’ll give you the ammunition you need to make a convincing argument for this powerful language, and how to respond to the usual FUD arguments you get. I’ll also let you in on some “sneaky” ways to get Go into your business.

2. Python, Go, and the Cost of Concurrency in the Cloud by Chris Erway (Chief Architect, AppNeta)


This talk will discuss how Go’s ability to provide easy concurrency have an impact on not just performance, but also your AWS bill!  As a case study we will present an event-processing service in production at AppNeta that we moved from Python to Go last year.  This service stores unique data blobs at a rate of roughly 1000/sec, each on average 70KB in size, and the talk walks through a few approaches to meeting this demand cost-effectively using cloud services such as Amazon S3, SQS, Kinesis, and DynamoDB.


The service was originally written in Python, and while scripting languages like Python, Ruby, and Node.js offer a fun and fast hacking experience (without the extra boilerplate or semicolons required by "less fun" languages) all three suffer from the same basic limitation — a single-threaded interpreter that cannot perform concurrent computation.  To make use of multiple cores, a programmer typically must run many processes in separate interpreters, and use IPC to communicate between them.  Support for asynchronous I/O as available in Node.js, Python's Tornado, Gevent, Twisted, or Ruby's EventMachine offers some ability to parallelize some I/O, but not computation.


However Go seems to offer the best of both worlds: fun hacking without the semicolons, but also easy access to concurrency and a compiler offering type-checking and runtime performance much faster than scripting languages.  Chris Erway, chief architect at AppNeta, will prevent a case study of a service that was ported from Python to Go last year, and how doing so resulted not just in better performance, but also a much more cost-efficient service — over 80% cheaper than the most naive implementation, and over 2x cheaper than the Python implementation’s deployment.

Our thanks go out to Akamai for the venue, food and drinks.

Here's to a great 2016!

·  SSRS enhancements and Mobile reports

About this month’s speaker:ANTHONY MARTIN


Principal Consultant

Anthony Martin is a data professional with over 10 years of experience designing and implementing solutions utilizing the Microsoft SQL Server Business Intelligence platform. As a Solutions Architect at Pragmatic Works, he provides training and consulting services to solve a wide array of business and technical challenges. He has obtained the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert in Business Intelligence certification. results.description:
Can you onsight a startup? 

#StartupClimb brings together rock climbers of all levels that are in the startup community. The talk is free, and it's $19 to climb you can pay when you come in, just mention you're with the startup group. 


Agenda

6:45PM Registration

7:00PM Talk w/Elias Torres

7:30PM - ? Closing time is 11:30 PM, climb as long as you like!

Speaker Bio

Elias Torres is on his fourth startup and is a 2X co-founder and CTO. He is focused on one thing only, Driftt, where he’s helping marketers transform their relationships with customers to drive retention & growth. Prior to Driftt, Elias was the VP of Engineering at HubSpot [NYSE:HUBS], which he joined through the acquisition of his startup, Performable, in 2011. He rebuilt the engineering team and product to position the company for success in their 2014 IPO.

Elias has spent the past 15 years in Boston, starting with his MS in Computer Science at Harvard, loving his family and enjoying everything New England has to offer such as kitesurfing, skiing and rock climbing. He is obsessed with finding the best talent, sculpting company culture, and building the next anchor company in Boston.

Sponsor

Brooklyn Boulders (#BKBS @bkbsomerville on Twitter / Instagram) Somerville is a 40,000 sq. ft. rock climbing and fitness facility in Somerville, Massachusetts that offers a new type of community space that blends state-of-the-art climbing terrain with art, culture, music, and entrepreneurship. Brooklyn Boulders is a dynamic creative community. BKB Somerville strives to maintain a strong connection with its community in various efforts such as inviting local graffiti artists to display their work and planning our youth events around local school schedules. Whether you’re a seasoned 5.13 climber or just found yourself interested in trying something new, come to BKB Somerville and find what you’re looking for.

results.description:
This will be the fifth session of our new Current Events meetup series (**NO prior attendance required). We aim to have reoccurring discussions moving forward so we can stay abreast of local, national, and global anti-racism issues both as individuals and together as a community. We have seen a huge surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Have a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting that isn't listed below? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Know of a local story/action/event that may not be getting coverage? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share a current event you've learned about over the past month or so. If not, feel free to come and listen, learn, and participate in some really important discussions. Looking forward to seeing you all there and continuing this new series! 

Possible January Current Events:

- Oregon "militia" armed protest

- Flint water crisis

- No charge against cop who murdered Tamir Rice

- Trump's fuckery

- Whitewashed Oscars 

Review from December:


- Trump

- Syrian Refugee Crisis
results.name: Current Events January

There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

results.description:
Science for the Public
Tuesday, January 26, 2016 at 6:30 PM
Belmont Media Center, 9 Lexington St, Belmont

GAMMA RAY BURSTS
Raul Jimenez, Ph.D.
Professor of Theoretical Physics and Astrophysics, ICREA/University of Barcelona; Radcliffe Fellow, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, Harvard University (see event link for his other academic titles)

Gamma-ray bursts are the most powerful explosions in the universe. Dr. Jimenez discusses how he and his colleagues analyze the relationship between GRBs and life: areas of the universe where planets might be relatively safe --or not-- from the destructive force of GRB radiation. Earth, we learn, has been relatively fortunate, but at least one of the ancient mass extinctions on our planet may have been due to the radiation from a GRB.
results.name: Science for the Public:  Gamma Ray Bursts w/ Raul Jiminez, Ph.D.

results.description:
Happy New Year to all ODLUG New Englanders. We've been targeting early 2016 for our second session and as end-2015 approached we agreed to hold a joint session in January with the Boston Software Networkers. 

For this first MeetUp we will have one NFV talk, one ODL talk, and a general brainstorm on future topics that are of highest and emergent value. In the next several days ahead, we will announce the speakers, talk titles and the abstracts.  

I believe that visibility, analytics and management will be at the top of most minds and I will pursue the NFV talk around these key characteristics. I would appreciate hearing from any of you with additional ideas around this or other topics for our inaugural meeting.  

Bring your ideas, your challenges and your appetite. Red Hat hosts us and the pizza and drinks will be provided by Brocade. Looking forward to seeing all of you to start this new year.


(Thank you to Mark Presti of Boston Software Networkers for the copy, which I shamelessly stole for our page: DN) \

Update:


• Developing for Applications for ODL:

Dave Lenrow of Huawei will share a presentation and his observations on the importance of policy enforcement and how Intents approaches the problem of network QoS enforcement for ODL.

• NFV:

Dave Neary will share his observations on Open NFV (OPNFV) and some slides ahead of his presentation at the upcoming FOSDEM event


We will also review open software development news and will take suggestions for topics at upcoming meetups.

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.
results.name: Board Games in Sudbury

THE HAPPINESS OF CONTENTMENT                                                                                                      a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | JANUARY 5th - 26th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

In our search for happiness, we use our time and energy seeking so many different things. We may change our job, our partner, our home, our situation, but we will never know real satisfaction until we change our restless, discontented mind. The mind of attachment is the main cause of our discontentment, relationship difficulties and craving.

In this drop-in meditation series we will learn practical methods and meditations that enable us to let go of attachment and find peace in all of our circumstances. Life doesn’t always go as planned but through the practice of contentment we can learn to keep a happy mind in all situations.

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
7 pm - News, OWASP tools, documents review

7:20 pm - Black Duck Software presents - Static analysis, dynamic analysis, and other testing tools are all essential weapons against adversaries.  But for the 80%+ of companies worldwide that use open source software in their application development these tools are ineffective in identifying and mitigating open source security risks . This presentation will cover:

The value of static and dynamic tools, and where they best fit in the Secure Development Lifecycle          

Why these tools are not useful in identifying known vulnerabilities in open source components          

Controls development and security professionals can deploy to select, detect, manage and monitor open source for existing and newly disclosed vulnerabilities

Food will be provided by Constant Contact.

Park in the front of the building and enter in the main building lobby, continue down the hallway and you will see the innovation center, enter in the large glass doors.


ALSO -  Software Development Life Cycle - Akshat Pradhan

The SDLC. One engineer said it was an abstract concept. Another engineer mentioned it was Agile. And someone else said it's a Life Cycle. In this talk, we're going to discuss the SDLC.

About

Akshat Pradhan is Founder and Product Director of ComplianceChamp - a consultancy service to manage your compliance (i.e. ISO 27001, PCI-DSS, HIPAA, FEDRAMP, SOC2). In addition to auditing, Akshat loves bringing people together to learn from each other, grow their capabilities, and collaborate to build secure things. For the past 6 years, he's been chair and organizer of the Boston Security Meetup - growing it from 0 to 2400+ members. Boston Security Meetup is the second largest hacker organization on Earth after OWASP NYC!

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Training in mindfulness we become familiar with our innate capacity for focused attention. How can we identify when our practice of focused attention has become fixation? How can focused attention remain open and permeable without distraction? Using the guidance from Tibetan Buddhist stages of meditation, Lama Samten will offer instructions that can be applied for any level of practice. Join Lama Samten and the NDF Cambridge Sangha in person or via LiveStream (http://www.naturaldharma.org/live-teachings). 

Since graduating from the traditional Tibetan Buddhist three-year retreat under the guidance of Lama Norlha Rinpoche, Lama Samten has devoted her energy and creativity towards connecting a wide range of students to their innate compassion and embodied wisdom. With an accessible and gentle presence she gently guides students using the teachings of the Buddha Dharma and yogic practices. In addition to being a core teacher for Natural Dharma Fellowship she is a contributing teacher to Kagyu Thubten Choling Monastery and its affiliate centers. Through facilitating group learning contexts (sangha), it is her wish to inspire the innate wisdom, compassion, and creativity that is every being’s destiny. She values the gifts of Buddhist practice that facilitate connecting intimately with the human experience each of us is a light into, as well as the power that this awareness offers to transforming suffering into resiliency and wisdom. Called to leverage an ethic of interdependence within the globalized socio-cultural context we are now living, she is grateful to connect with colleagues and communities across many disciplines including the arts, education, activism, and psychotherapy.

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.
results.name: Concentration and Fixation: A Dharma Teaching with Lama Samten Bryn Dawson

The Buddhist "Way".

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS IS A 6-WEEK CLASS STARTING TUESDAY, JANUARY 26TH AND GOING THROUGH MARCH 1ST. CLASSES WILL BE EVERY TUESDAY EVENING FROM 7-9:30

**PRE-REGISTRATION REQUIRED. SIMPLY CLICKING MEETUP WILL NOT HOLD YOUR SPOT.

Everything you experience is preceded by a vibration of energy. However, do you find that you struggle to create what you want because you've given away your energy--physically and emotionally--but don't know how to get it back? Energy Meditation 101 is a 6-week class of playful, practical, and powerful tools that will teach you how to work with energy. The tools taught in this class are based on unique meditation, intuitive development, and guided imagery techniques and can be applied in all areas of your life--from work and relationships to health and home--and used to grow your awareness and understanding. 

***This class is especially recommended for those looking for a fun and non-traditional approach to meditation as well as experienced healers who are looking for tools to grow their abilities and certainty. 

Week 1: Learn what energy is, how to release the energy you don't want like stress, pain, and invalidation--and call back your unique vibration of energy. We'll learn a powerful tool for releasing energy out of our bodies and environments. 

Week 2: Learn about your body's energetic system and how to tap into a key intuitive ability that will help you create and change energy. 

Week 3: Learn about two very dynamic and safe energies that can be used to heal your body and energy system. 

Week 4: Learn a tool for creating energetic boundaries and keeping out unwanted energy. Week 

Week 5: Learn a simple and fun tool for creating different energetic vibrations.

Week 6: Learn a dynamic tool that enables your body and energetic system to work together to easily create your dreams and goals. 

Jill Alexander holds a Master’s degree from Lesley University in Energy Medicine, a Reiki certification from Brigham & Women's Hospital, and presenting pursuing Healing Touch (HT) certification.  She has done energy work in hospitals, doctor's offices, and private practice and has been published research on energy work in the International Journal of Healing and Caring. Jill is a graduate of The Clairvoyant Center of Hawaii and has 15 years of training in energy work.

results.description:
Hello, and welcome to another edition of the Manga Club! For all returning and new members, let’s start off this year with a bang!

This month, we will be doing a comparison between disasters using what I like to call the classroom catastrophe trope. Basically, it consists of what normal, everyday students will do to overcome a massive, extremely dangerous situation that they are thrust into without any warning. These can include natural disasters, demonic or alien invasion or zombie apocalypse to name a few. Or, as shown in the selected titles, a combination of all three! So, for your comparison, Assassination Classroom volume 1 by Yusei Matsui and Magical Girl Apocalypse volume 1 by Kentaro Sato!

Assassination Classroom Volume 1 by Yusei Matsui

The students in Class 3-E of Kunugigaoka Junior High have a new teacher: an alien octopus with bizarre powers and unlimited strength, who’s just destroyed the moon and is threatening to destroy the earth—unless they can kill him first!

Meet the would-be assassins of class 3-E: Sugino, who let his grades slip and got kicked off the baseball team. Karma, who's doing well in his classes but keeps getting suspended for fighting. And Okuda, who lacks both academic and social skills, yet excels at one subject: chemistry. Who has the best chance of winning that reward? Will the deed be accomplished through pity, brute force or poison...? And what chance does their teacher have of repairing his students' tattered self-esteem?

Magical Girl Apocalypse volume 1 by Kentaro Sato

Not your mommy's magical girls!

High-schooler Kii Kogami is stuck in a rut, loathing the monotonous doldrums of his everyday life. If only something exciting were to happen, something magical. As fate would have it, Kii is about to get his wish, but in a way more terrifying than anything he could have imagined.
When a little girl clad in gothic lolita attire appears at school and starts to gruesomely bludgeon, dismember and mutilate all who cross her path, while chanting the mantra "Magical Girl" from her corpse-like lips, the school devolves into a state of bloody chaos.

Just how will Kii escape from this murderous magical girl? To make matters worse, the magical girl's victims reanimate and join her killer rampage as minions. Is there no way out of school for hapless Kii Kogami? And even if he escapes, what will be left of the world outside?

A limited number of copies will be at the venue, and don’t forget our special deal! On the night of the Manga Club, all participants get ten percent off all graphic novels in the store, and twenty five percent off any future Manga Club title releases in stock! So if you come to the November Manga Club event, you can get the December title for twenty five percent off as available! This does not include any other specials that the venue might be running that night as well.

BUT PLEASE REMEMBER, THIS DISCOUNT ONLY APPLIES TO VOLUMES IN THE STORE ON THE NIGHT OF A MANGA CLUB EVENT! THIS DISCOUNT DOES NOT APPLY AT ANY OTHER TIME OR TO A PREVIOUSLY RESERVED GRAPHIC NOVEL! THIS DEAL IS A GIFT NOT A PRIVILEGE SO PLEASE DO NOT ABUSE IT!

Thank you again for all your support this year and I hope to see you there!
results.name: January Manga Club! Classroom Catastrophe!

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
Come meditate with us every Tuesday and Friday at 8pm in our beautiful public meditation center. We offer a short (10 minute) introductory talk about a Buddhist topic and conclude with a half hour meditation session. Meditation is always free and guided in English. Everyone is welcome to come and explore their minds highest potential!

Street parking is available on the corner of Rockingham and Granite street and along Granite.  There is also a large parking lot with a Trader Joe's 2 minutes walk away from the center.

Cambridge, MA 02139

results.description:
Iconic fighting style of many cultures the sword and shield have been in use for centuries. This class teaches the fundamentals of using a single-handed sword and combining that with a shield.

The Common program is appropriate for Viking, Medieval and Highland Scots methods of fighting with the Sword & Shield.

The program is developed from primarily 18th century sources such as Thomas Page. As well as from the modern work of Christopher Scott Thompson.

The program starts with development of carrying out basic skills plus the buckler and grows towards advanced buckler specific techniques.
results.name: Common Sword & Shield

group.name: Athena School of Arms - Historical Swordsmanship

results.description:
We will be playing indoors at the Mansfield Sports Plex (31 Oxford Rd, Mansfield, MA).  They have both courts and a turf field.  We can use cleats, sneakers, or indoor soccer shoes on the turf field, but only sneakers/indoor soccer shoes on the courts.  

Come prepared to play on either surface because if we get too many for the turf, we'll have to split into two games (one on turf and the other on the courts).

I believe we will be limited to the courts as the turf is probably unavailable.


Cost should be about $10 per person.

Also bring both a white and dark shirt to help split into teams.

We are joining another group of players, so there should be enough to play even if there aren't many RSVPs.

Thanks,

-Dave

results.description:
Ski / Ride Mt. Sunapee $36. Wednesday Jan. 27th. 8:30 am. Mt Sunapee Ski area. rt. 103 Newbury NH. Host: Steve Ob1. [masked]  [masked]  Carpooling from Nashua, Manchester, & Concord NH.. Two-Fer (2-for-1) Wednesdays: Two people can ski / ride all day only $72. -Take the day off. You get so much more skiing and riding on the weekdays. Than you do on the weekends. The parking is in front of the lodge. Not miles away from it. The lodge, the lift lines and the trails are all empty.  So, please join Steve Ob1. and friends for an easy day of skiing 2 for 1 price is $35.90 each lift ticket. Steve Ob1. is a PSIA ski instructor and is happy to ski at almost any level. But, he prefers not to do extreme skiing. We stop to talk and to enjoy the views around. If you want some help with your skiing skills? Steve will be happy to help. If he is asked. Otherwise, he is here to ski like everyone.  Also, to get 40 % off any weekdays & 10% on weekends. You can get your Free Rewards Card. See the link below, or call Ski & Golf. This link does not always work. So, you may have to call or stop by one of their stores.   http://www.golfskiwarehouse.com/rewards_partners_mtsun.aspx

All-Star Rewards Partner Programs - Mount Sunapee Mount Sunapee Resort

http://skinh.com/tickets-and-deals/daily-ticket-deals.aspx  Winter or summer, Mount Sunapee is your mountain getaway. Mount Sunapee has the most reliable snow in the East. For the past 14 years Mount Sunapee has averaged a #3 ranking in the East for both snow quality and grooming in the annual SKI Magazine reader survey. During the summer the new Adventure Park offers a Canopy Zip-Line Tour, Aerial Challenge Course with 32 challenges, guided off-road Segway® PT Excursions, an 18-hole championship Disc Golf course and 18 holes of Miniature Golf.

The big mountain with the best snow in the East is right in your backyard.

Mount Sunapee Resort is conveniently located in southern New Hampshire in close proximity to interstates I-89 and I-91.To check on snow conditions and weather

click here  All-Star Rewards Members enjoy: 40% off a mid-week, non-holiday period one-day lift ticket$10.00 off a weekend or holiday period one-day lift ticket*

Restrictions: Discount applies to daily full-price, full-day, all-mountain lift tickets only.Special or promotional rates do not apply. Cannot be combined with any other offer. Maximum one ticket per card per day.All-Star Rewards card must be presented to the Guest Services Desk to receive your discounted ticket. Lift Ticket Redemption Procedures: Calling hours:Monday–Friday, 9am-5pm (EST), at (603)[masked]

You must present your All-Star Rewards card at the Guest Services desk in either the Sunapee or Spruce Lodge to pick up your ticket.

To learn more about Mount Sunapee or for driving directions, log onto www.mountsunapee.com/mtsunapeewinter.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
